On Thursday last I saw the prosecutor, as I was standing against the door of the Stingo, smoking a pipe; he accused me of being one of the prisoner's accomplices in the theft - I was at the Yorkshire Stingo on the night in question; I am well known there - it was between seven and eight o'clock last Thursday evening when the prosecutor came to me with the Policeman; the prosecutor appeared to me as drunk as any person could be, and so was the Policeman - they were not fit to walk; the Policeman had a sealing-wax pipe in his mouth, and I said it was fine times for a Policeman to have a sealingwax pipe - I said if he was not quiet I would give charge of him to another officer.

COURT. Q. What coach do you drive? A. I was driving a coach, but am out of work - I now wash coaches for a gentleman who has an omnibus; it is six or seven months since I drove a coach - I was in service seven years ago, but my master is in France; I did drive for a Mr. Trivett six or seven months ago - I used to drive odd journies: coachmen would not get so drunk as the prosecutor and the Policeman were - I was at the Stingo that very night; the prosecutor was very drunk - I did not help him home: it is the worst thing in the world to help people home who are in liquor - he could not run; he could shuffle along.
Prisoner. The Policeman who took me to the soldier was full fifty yards off me.
JOSEPH HAINSWORTH. The prosecutor was about eight yards behind him. GUILTY.
The indictment further stated that the prisoner had previously been convicted of felony.

JOSEPH STONE
. I am one of the City night-patrol. I produce the copy of the conviction of the prisoner - I was a witness on the trial and know he is the man - (read.)

Prisoner. Q. Since I have been convicted has it not been clearly understood who the persons were who committed the robbery? A. No, not by me, I certainly never had an idea that you were not the person, and never said any thing of the kind.
Prisoner. I have been unjustly convicted in one instance and am sacrificed in another - he has been with the people every day. Witness. I merely waited expecting the cause to be called.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Life .

909.
MARY ANN WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March , 1 blanket, value 2s.; 1 candlestick, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 3s.; 1 rug, value 2s.; 1 bolster. value 5s.; 1 table-cover, value 2s.; 1 coverlid, value 1s., and 2 pillows, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Gibbs
.

EDWARD GIBBS
. I live in Tonbridge-street. St. Pancras
. On the 5th of October I let the prisoner a furnished lodging, as a married woman, and a night or two after she introduced a person who she said was her husband - he used to come two or three nights in a week and sleep there; I was urgent upon him, and he went away - she said he had broken his leg; I desired her to go, but she would not, and I put in a broker - this property was missing and these duplicates of it were found.

CHARLES FREDERICK FIELD
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker, in Somers'-town. This property was all pawned with me by the prisoner at different times.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I had a blind mother, and I would not sit and see her starving while I had any thing to make away with.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Seven Years .

910.
JOHN PRATT
and
JAMES BLYTHE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of February
, 1 iron bar, value 2s. , the goods of
William Larkin
; and
CHARLOTTE INGLESBY
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen .

MARY LARKIN. I am the wife of
William Larkin
- we live in the Commercial-road
. We lost an iron bar from the yard on the 22nd of February; it belonged to our shutter; Pratt lived in Grub-street, and Blythe in Glasshousefields.

HENRY SHAW
. I am a Police-officer. I apprehended Pratt in Brook-street, half a mile from the prosecutor's - he had nothing with him.

EDWARD YOUNG
. I am a Police-serjeant. I went with Shaw to Brook-street, to the residence of Inglesby -Pratt went to shew us the house; the woman said she had not had a bar - I asked Pratt if that was the woman; he said it was - I asked if she had sold any iron; she said, Yes, to Mr. Philpot of Love-lane; after a considerable time I told her she must have purchased the bar, as Pratt would take his oath that was the shop. and she was the person; after some time a little girl came from the parlour with this bar - the woman looked at me and said,"Oh, la! what shall I do," or words to that effect; the words were very faint.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see her daughter? A. Yes - she appeared fifteen or sixteen years old; I do not know that she attends in the shop in her mother's absence.

WILLIAM THOMAS
. I took up Blythe at his mother's house - I said, "I want you, you know something about an iron bar;" he at first denied it - I said, "We have got the boy in custody, was you with him?" he said, "I was," and stated where the bar was sold - I asked if they wenton purpose to steal it; he said No, but he carried it to be sold, and they sold it for 3d.; I had taken Pratt the evening before - he said he had stolen the bar, and he should not mind if the other boy was taken up.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he tell you that he had fabricated a story; that he had picked it out of the water and it had fallen from a ship? A. No.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Blythe's Defence. I was going along and met this boy, who said, "Where are you going?" I said, "Home;" he said, "Here is a bit of iron, shall we take it?" I said, No - he said, "It will get a bit of bread," and he took the bar; I stood outside while he went in, and told the woman he had picked it up as a ship was unloading at the saltpetre warehouse, and it was wet - she said, "Are you sure of that?" he said, Yes; she gave him 3d. for it.

PRATT -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Six Weeks .

BLYTHE and INGLESBY -
NOT GUILTY .

911.
THOMAS YOUNG
was
indicted for embezzlement .

BENJAMIN WELLS
. The prisoner was in my employ, but was not to receive money for me; he sent his brother-in-law to receive this money in my name.
NOT GUILTY .

912.
THOMAS TAYLOR
was
indicted for embezzlement .

BENJAMIN JOSEPH
. I am a broker , and live in Wardour-street - the prisoner was my shopman , and was to receive money for me, which he was to bring to me or my wife; he never accounted to me for 10l., received from Mr. Clark, who had purchased a table of me for nine guineas, and I sent it home.

WILLIAM CLARK
. I purchased a table of the prosecutor, and he was to send the balance of a 10l. note - I gave the note to the prisoner.

BENJAMIN JOSEPH
. He never returned, and I thought some accident might have happened to him; I went to Mr. Clark's, at Maida-hill, who showed me the receipt - I went with his mother to a lodging, which he had taken that day in St. Giles'; we waited till half-past one o'clock in the morning when he came home - his mother questioned him how he could do as he had done; he gave up the balance, 5l. 2s. 6d., which he had, and acknowledged he had bought some books, and bought a man, in his company, a new coat - he said he had spent 3l. odd, and the rest he could not give any account of; he had behaved very well till this time, and I did not wish to prosecute him had it not been on account of his obstinacy - I should think he could get employ again; he was a little in liquor- I cannot say he was drunk.
GUILTY. Aged 18.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Judgment Respited .

913.
JOSEPH BISHOP
and
WILLIAM WOOD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February
, 2 bags, value 1s., and 1 bushel of turnips, value 2s., the goods of
Richard Laycock
, their master ; and
THOMAS AM-BROSE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. CRESWELL conducted the prosecution.

RICHARD LAYCOCK
. I am a cowkeeper , and live at Islington; Bishop and Wood were in my employ at 18s. a week. On the 13th of February I sent them to Westham
for turnips - I sent a superintendent with them, as I have lately been obliged to do; I never suffer any one to glean turnips or any thing else off my land - I expected them to return about six o'clock in the evening, but they did not; the officer came to give me some information - I have seen the nose-bags which were with them that day; I saw the turnips at the watch-house - they were the same kind as mine, but I cannot swear to them.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. When had you seen them? A. I cannot tell; I saw them before I bought them, and I saw them afterwards - we buy them by the acre; I do not suffer people to glean - they may do it, but it is not a common thing.
COURT. Q. Did you see the turnips, said to be left at Ambrose's? A. Yes, and those which came home with the cart - they appeared to be the same sort.

THOMAS CROUCH
. I am foreman to Mr. Laycock. On the 13th of February I went to West-ham, when the two prisoners went with the carts - the horses had nose-bags on their heads at Old Ford; that was the last I saw of them; they were then taken off, and tied on the shafts - the corn was very nearly all consumed then; there were three nosebags then - I afterwards missed two bags, and when I got to Dalston-lane I missed Bishop; I stopped the team, and rode back, but could see nothing of him - I went home, and heard that the prisoners were at the watch-house; these are the bags.

CHARLES HORTON PULLEY
. I am a solicitor and vestry clerk, of Hackney. On the 13th of February I was returning home, down Dalston-lane - I had passed Ambrose's house about thirty yards, when I saw Bishop adjusting his nose-bag full of turnips at the back of his cart- my suspicions were excited, and I walked to within ten yards of Ambrose's house, where there is a sharp angle; I saw Wood carrying into Ambrose's house another nose-bag of turnips; I walked in through the house, into the bake-house, and saw both the prisoners there - Bishop had shot his bag of turnips, and Wood shot his; I said they must put them into the bags again, and go to the watch-house, which they did, after some hesitation - I saw a large quantity of turnips under a dresser there.
Cross-examined. Q. Did they say any thing to you? A. They said they had gleaned them off the land, but did not say where.
MR. LAYCOCK. I believe them to be mine.

Cross-examined. Q. Are they not really quite a different kind of turnip to yours? A. They really are not; there might be two days difference in the sowing of them - I had a very high opinion of these men, till I had reason to believe to the contrary.
Bishop's Defence. There were some scattered about the ground, which were not my master's; the ground was ploughed where they had been sown, and I took them up.

BISHOP -
GUILTY . Aged 31.

WOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Three Months .

AMBROSE -
NOT GUILTY .

914.
JAMES SHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of March , two boxes, value 20s., the goods of
James Powell
, and that he had been previously convicted of felony .

JAMES POWELL. I live in Prince's-street, Westminser
. On the 30th of March I heard the latch of my shop-door go, as I was in my parlour; I looked into the shop and saw the prisoner walk in - my little girl went into the shop, and said "Some one will come directly," and went to ring the bell; the prisoner at that time put something in his righthand pocket, which I thought was a shell; he then said he would call again; I saw him stoop and put something into his left-hand pocket - I said Halloo, stop! he made a rush out and broke a pane of glass; I said to Mrs. Powell,"A man has run out and taken two shells in his pocket, run and call stop thief!" - in three minutes be was brought back to the shop; he said he had broken the window - I went and put my hand into his pocket, and partly pulled out a box; the officer then took him; these are my boxes - I had nothing on but my shirt and stockings at the time.

GEORGE CLIFFORD
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner, and have the property. GUILTY.

ROBERT TURNER
. I am an officer of St. George's, Hanover-square. I have a copy of the record of the prisoner's conviction, on the 10th of September, in the tenth year of his present Majesty's reign - I was a witness, and know he is the man. (Record read.)

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Life .

915.
JAMES OSBORN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 3 trowels, value 5s., the goods of
Joshua Faint
; and 1 trowel, value 1s., the goods of
William Lewis
; and that on the 18th of February last he was convicted of felony by the name of
James Morell
.

JAMES MANNING. I am a bricklayer's labourer. I was working at No. 6, Taylor-street, Carnaby-market
, on the 15th of March, which was undergoing repair - I saw the prisoner there five minutes after six o'clock; Faint had left at three because it was wet - I was going out when the bricklayer told me to go up for his jacket; I went up and saw the prisoner in the two-pair front room on his knees, with his hat beside him - he was taking the tools out of the box and putting them into his handkerchief; I stood behind him and asked what he was doing- he said he was coming to finish this job; I said,"There are some men here besides you" - he said, "I am come to do it;" - he took a trowel and began to beat some mortar - I took him in charge; he had not been at work there.
Prisoner. You asked me what I was doing, and I said I came from Mr. Croxon, the builder; I was on my hands and knees mixing up the mortar, and you struck me. Witness. I did not.

JOSEPH FAINT. I am a journeyman bricklayer
. I left at three o'clock, on account of the rain, and had put my tools away; these three trowels are mine.
WILLIAM LEWIS. I am a journeyman bricklayer. This trowel is mine. I had left it in the same box; the prisoner had no right there.
Prisoner. Faint knows me and my father and mother.

JOSEPH FAINT
. Yes, I know all the family; I came from the same village in Hertfordshire. GUILTY.

JOHN LANDON
. I am an officer. I got this certificate of the prisoner's former conviction from Mr. Clark's office; on the 18th of February last the prisoner was convicted of felony, by the name of
James Morell
- I was a witness and know he is the man - (certificate read.)

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Life .

916.
ALFRED GAZELEY
and
JOHN MUNN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of March , 130 lbs. of pork, value 3l., the goods of
John Ambler
; and that, on the 16th of July, the said
Alfred Gazeley
, was convicted of felony .

BENJAMIN AMBLER
. I am the son of
John Ambler
, of Ball's-pond
. On the 8th of March my father killed a pig, and hung it in the front yard; I and my father sat up that night in the shed, and three other persons sat up in the stable, as we had lost three pigs before; at two o'clock in the morning the two prisoners came together - they got over two high sences into the back yard, and I saw no more of them till they were bringing this dead pig back, which had been in a new shed in the front yard; they were both carrying it - it weighed eighteen stone - we took them, and this time we saved the pig; I have seen Gazeley before.
WILLIAM SHEPPARD. I am a groom. I was in the front yard, and saw the prisoners come to the pork; Munn untied the rope, and Gazeley took it on his back - they then both carried it.

JOSEPH TODD
. I was watching at the place, and took the prisoners.
Gazeley's Defence. We leave it to the mercy of the Court.

MUNN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

THOMAS COPE
. I am an officer of Islington. I have a certificate of the former conviction of Gazeley - I took him, and was at the trial; I know he is the man.

GAZELEY -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Life .

917.
JOHN COOPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 table, value 16s. , the goods of
Thomas Goode
.

JAMES SWAIN
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Woollard. On the 12th of April, between seven and eight o'clock, I saw the prisoner take a table from outside Mr. Goode's shop, opposite the window; I gave an alarm - he put it down at the corner of Crown-street, and ran off; there was a cry of Stop thief! and he was taken in five or ten minutes - I lost sight of him as he turned Charles-street, Pitfield-street; I am sure he is the person.

ELIZABETH ALLEN
. I lodge at Mr.
Thomas Goode
's, in Old Street-road
. This table was near his shop-door - the witness ran up stairs to me; as I came down the table was brought into the shop by an errand-boy; I went round the corner to look for my husband, and picked up the prisoner's hat - this is the table.
JAMES SWAINE. As the prisoner was putting his head under the table, his hat fell off.

JOSEPH ELISHES
. I am errand-boy to Mr. Goode. I saw the prisoner put the table down at the corner of Crown-street; I had not seen him take it up - I called out Stop thief! I did not see him caught, but saw him immediately afterwards - he dropped his hat.

JOHN JOHNSON
. I was in conversation with a friend, at the corner of Crown-street; I saw a man coming with a table on his shoulder - there was a cry of Stop thief! heput it down and ran off - my friend pursued him; he was without a hat.
Prisoner's Defence. A man rushed round the corner and took off my hat - I ran after him, and a man gave charge of me.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 25.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

918.
ELIZABETH BUMPSTEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February , 4 pewter pot, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Butt
, and 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
James Scull
.

EDMUND BUTT. I keep the Black Cap public-house, Camden-town
. Four of these pots are mine; I know nothing about the prisoner.

JAMES SCULL
. I am a publican. I keep the Wheat Sheaf public-house
. This pot is mine.

WILLIAM JAMIESON. I am an officer. On Wednesday, the 24th of February, I saw the prisoner in Camden-town; I followed her across the fields - I came up and stopped her; I found these five pots in a stuff petticoat under her apron - she begged me to let her go.
The prisoner made a long Defence, stating she was a widow with six children, and had not the means of providing for them.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Transported for Seven Years .

919.
EDWARD WILLIAMS
and
THOMAS MORGAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March , 24 stockings, value 15s. , the goods of
William Kipling
.

THOMAS FOGG
. I am a Thames Police-constable. On the 18th of March I was in Rosemary-lane; I saw the two prisoners in company - Morgan was carrying this bundle under his apron; I asked what he had there - he said, some stockings, which a person employed him to sell for him - I told him to show me the person; I went with them down the lane, and then they said it was of no use telling a lie about it, and Williams added, "We stole them out of Cheapside."

THOMAS STILL
. I am in the employ of Mr.
William Kipling
, a hosier, in Cheapside. These are his property, and were missed, on the 18th of March, from a stool near the door, in our shop - there are twelve pairs tied up, and they have our mark on them; I did not see the prisoners.
Morgan's Defence. I was in distress, through my master being a bankrupt.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY , Aged 18.

MORGAN -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

920.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of March , 1 truck, value 3l. , the goods of
George Sanderson
.

GEORGE SANDERSON. I live at Edmonton
, this truck is mine. and was in the yard in front of my house on the evening of the 22nd of March, and the next morning at six o'clock I saw it in Bunhill-row; I know nothing of the prisoner.

GEORGE SHEPHERD
. I am a Police-officer. On the 23rd of March I was on duty, and saw the prisoner coming with this truck in a direction from Kingsland-road to Shoreditch; I asked where he was going to take it - he said it belonged to a man named Brown, in Tower-street, and he was sent down to a person named Francis at Edmonton, with fourteen pieces of wood - I did not think it was a correct story, and I took him into custody: in the course of a week I found the prosecutor.
Prisoner. I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Three Months .

921.
JOHN WILTSHIRE
and
JOHN COOKE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of March , 1 tea-kettle, value 4s. 10d. , the goods of
John Northfield
.

JAMES TAYLOR
. I am a butcher, and live in the Cityroad. On the 26th of March I saw the two prisoners together, in Bath-street, not ten minutes walk from the prosecutor's - Wiltshire had an apron, and when I got close to them, I saw the spout of this tea-kettle; I passed them and saw them turn up a court - I went round Old-street, and saw them again; Cooke had then got the apron on, and the kettle open in his hand - I told the officer; I ran and took Cooke and Barrows took Wiltshire - I found these boots on Cooke, and a duplicate of an article pawned the same day.

JAMES BARROWS
. I am an officer. Taylor pointed out the two prisoners; Cooke had an apron on, and this kettle in his hand.

ROBERT SANGSTER NORTHFIELD
. I am the son of
John Northfield
, an ironmonger . This is his kettle, it had been outside his house in the City-road
, on a stove by the window: it has my mark on it.

JOHN BEDFORD
. I was serjeant of the Police. The prisoners were brought in, and charged with stealing this tea-kettle; when I was taking them to Worship-street, I heard Cooke ask Wiltshire what he should say - he said he did not know: Cooke said, "Say we found it" - Wiltshire said No; Cooke then said, "Say it was given you to carry:" and that was the defence they made before the Magistrate.

WILTSHIRE
GUILTY . Aged 21.

COOKE
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Three Months .

922.
WILLIAM MORRIS WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April , 1 handkerchief, value 4s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 2s. 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s. 6d. and 1 pair of braces, value 6d., the goods of
William Plant
, his master .

WILLIAM PLANT. I am a hosier , and live in Oxford-street
. The prisoner was in my employ rather more than two months; for three or four weeks before I gave him in charge. I observed a particular pattern silk waistcoat which he had, and I asked him if he had been helping himself to it, from my stock; he said No, Mr.
Edward Busby
and he had one a piece off the same silk - this was on Sunday; and the following day I looked over my stock, and missed one of these waistcoats: I kept a sharp look on him, but detected nothing else, till the night previous to my giving him into custody, when he and the apprentice got tipsy in my absence: the following day I got a friend to come, and ask for a similar waistcoat - I said to him, "Wood it is the same as you have, let the gentleman look at that:" he brought it down after some time, and in consequence of what I had heard, I gave him into custody - the officer then searched his box, and found theseother things, which are like what I had in the shop; but they are of that general character I could not identify them.

BENJAMIN WILLIAM VALENTINE
. I was sent for, and searched the prisoner's box; I found these articles, which the prosecutor said he had no doubt were his - here is a pair of stockings and a pair of gaiters; these braces are quite new - this waistcoat was brought to me by the prosecutor.

Mr. PLANT. I believe this waistcoat to be mine, and these braces he says he paid the apprentice for, who says he did not receive it; I have no such black stockings as these now, but I had such, and this handkerchief and drawers.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How many pieces of silk are there of this pattern? A. I cannot tell. These stockings I have more hesitation about than the other property; I sent the person to buy goods - the prisoner did not give me a true account of that, but I ultimately got the money.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the waistcoat at Mr. Webb's; the handkerchief I brought home from India.

JOHN RICHMOND WEBB
. I cannot recognize the prisoner as purchasing any waistcoat of me, but I had this pattern in my possession; he might have bought it at some other shop.

MARY THOMAS
. My husband is a labourer. I have known the prisoner twelve months; I have washed these stockings for him, before he went to the prosecutor's.
NOT GUILTY .

922.
SAMUEL NEWMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of March , 1 handkerchief, value 18d., the goods of
Joseph Smith
, from his person .

JOSEPH SMITH. I am a solicitor . On Sunday, the 21st of March, about eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Featherstone-street
; the prisoner took the handkerchief from my pocket - I turned round, and saw it in his hand; he flung it at me and ran; I pursued, and took him about one hundred and fifty yards off.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know this handkerchief? A. I think my initials are on it; here is a little hole in it - I did not feel any body at my pocket; I had my pocket-book in the same pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. There were three boys behind me; there were no others there.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Whipped and Discharged.
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

923.
HENRY WHALE DOYLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of March , 2 pocket-books, value 10s.; 1 box of portable pens, value 2s., and 1 tooth-pick, value 18d., the goods of
John Brooks
, his master .
The witnesses did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

924.
RICHARD WHITING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of February , 1 piece of coping-stone, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Want
and
John Richardson
.

EDWARD SPARROW
. I am a stone-mason. I saw the prisoner take the stone from the prosecutors' wharf, on the 19th of February, about two o'clock in the afternoon- I stopped him and asked where he was going; he said,"Just up here" - I said, "Come back, and tell me where you got it;" I took him back, and asked a man if he had allowed him to take it - he said No; I asked who sent him, and he said "A man round here;" I went round and saw two men and a woman - I said, "Was it either of them?" he said No.

JAMES RUSSELL
. I was working for Mr. Spencer; I was with Sparrow when we saw the prisoner with the stone.

RICHARD DRISCOLL
. I am in the employ of Want and Richardson. Mr. Sparrow called me out and asked if I had given the prisoner this stone; I said No.

JOHN RICHARDSON
. I am partner with Mr.
Thomas Want
; this is our property.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am an officer. I was called and took the prisoner; I asked what he was going to do with the stone - he said a man promised him a pint of beer to carry it.
Prisoner's Defence. A man called me and said, "If you will carry this stone, I will give you a pint of beer;" I took it and was stopped - the man went round the corner.
Mr. SPARROW. I saw him take it off the wharf, and there was but one way to go to it.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Three Months .

925.
MARY TOUMEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of March , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Alexander Cowan
.

LOUISA COWAN. I am the daughter of
Alexander Cowan
- he keeps a shop in Aylesbury-street, Clerkenwell
. I was at his door on the afternoon of the 22nd of March - a person told me a pair of shoes had been taken; I sent my brother after them - I missed one pair from the corner, which I had seen two or three days before; I had not seen my father hang them at the door.

LEWIS COWAN
. I am ten years of age. I found the prisoner with the shoes in her basket, and told her she must come back, which she did; I had seen the shoes that morning - my father hung them out - this was about twelve o'clock.

ALEXANDER COWAN
. These are my shoes.

HENRY BERESFORD
. I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked them up as I was passing the shop; the boy asked if I had picked up a pair of shoes - I said Yes; he said they were his father's - I said he should have them back.

LEWIS COWAN
. She did not say how she got them - she said, "Here are your shoes, I don't want them."

JURY to ALEXANDER COWAN. Q. Could not a person going by with a basket knock them down? A. No; they were on a line, which hung close to the window - they could not be got without lifting them up, or cutting them.
NOT GUILTY .

926.
SUSAN TAPE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of February , 3 table-cloths, value 14s.; 1 apron, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 1s., and 25s. in copper monies , the property of
Ambrose Charles
.

MARTHA ELIZABETH CHARLES
. I am the wife of
Ambrose Charles
. The prisoner came to assist my servant, who was ill - she came on the Monday, and staid till the Sunday night, when she absented herself; I missed this money from the parlour closet - I have seen the tablecloths, apron and cap since.

SAMUEL HASLOP
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a table-cloth, a pair of woman's shoes, and a shift, pawned with me; the table-cloth on the 10th of February, by the prisoner, I believe.

THOMAS SWEATMAN
. I am a grocer. I tied up these papers of halfpence, and paid them to Mr. Charles on Saturday evening, the 13th of February; I know these are the papers.

MARY COLLINS
. I lived servant at the place. The prisoner took these shoes, and this collar of mine.

JOHN WHITE
. I am an officer. I have a cap which I took from her, and this apron and copper money I found in a box which the landlady said was hers - these papers were about the money; one was tied up, and the other had been opened.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Seven Years .
There was another indictment against the prisoner, which was not tried.

927.
WILLIAM STEPHENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 2 doors, value 1l., and 1 wooden partition, value 14s. , the goods of
Samuel Emsley
.

SAMUEL EMSLEY. I am a stay-maker , and live in Kingsland-road
. I began building a manufactory seven months ago; I found all the materials - the prisoner was to find labourers, and do the carpenter's work. On Saturday, the 10th of April, I went to see if the workmen had come - I met the prisoner coming from my premises with some beads and timber - I asked him why he did not go on with his work; he said, "I do not mean to take these things, Mr. Emsley;" I said, "It looks very much like it"- he then said, "I did take them," and he went back and threw them down; I then went to another place, where he had a contract and was to find the materials - I there found two doors, which I knew belonged to me - he followed me- I said I should not leave him till I had given him in charge; he went with me to Bethnal-green, and I gave him in charge for stealing two doors, which he denied, and said he had them by him for twelve months - but at Worship-street he acknowledged he had taken them; I do not recollect the words he first used, but he said be bought them of Pain, my foreman - I knew the doors, and on the Tuesday following I found a partition that he was painting- I ordered him to desist, as it was mine; he said it was not, but he afterwards, before the Magistrate, said he bought them of my foreman.

Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Have you any partner in this building? A. No; the prisoner is a master carpenter - he walked with me till I gave him in charge; the exterior of the doors was the same as they were before he took them.

THOMAS PAIN
. I am foreman to the prosecutor. I never sold these, or any thing else to the prisoner - I was ordered to go and take two doors which the prosecutor considered belonged to him, which I did, and gave to the officer.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you never received any money from the prisoner? A. No; I never received 12s. 6d., nor ever sold him any thing.

JOHN COLLINS
. I work for the prosecutor. I know these doors are his.

JOHN COBHAM
. I am in the employ of the prosecutor. I know these doors are his.

JAMES MASON
. I employed the prisoner to build a cottage for me, at No. 30, Camden-gardens; he was to find the materials - that is where the doors were found; they had been there two or three weeks, and had not been altered or disfigured.

JAMES HAWKNAGE
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - he said he did not recollect who he bought them of- he had had them twelve months.
Witnesses for the Defence.

ROBERT HILL
. I am a carpenter, and live at No. 10, Reliance-square, New Inn-yard, Shoreditch. I worked for the prisoner on those premises; I saw him take these things away, and Pain handed them outside the door to him - I think it was this day month; there was only the prisoner, Pain, and myself on the premises.

THOMAS PAIN
. He might have seen me giving them out, but with no intention of his taking them away, nor did I know he was taking them; the frames were made to enclose the doors.
Cross-examined. Q. Do not you know they were taken away? A. Yes, but not by my orders; I gave them to be made use of.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 28.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury and Prosecutor .
Confined Eight Months .

928.
WILLIAM STANLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of March , 1 penknife, value 2s. , the goods of
William Elliott
.

MARY FELTS. I am servant to William Elliott - he is a tobacconist . On the 17th of March the prisoner came into his shop, and asked the price of some tobacco; he was told the price, and while Mr. Elliott turned away, he stole a penknife off the counter, took it out of the shop, and gave it to another boy - I called the Police-officer, and brought the prisoner back; it was a good knife.

THOMAS MIDDLETON
. I am the officer I took the prisoner; I found 1s. 6 1/2d. on him.
Prisoner's Defence. I went and asked the price of tobacco, came out, and went about a hundred yards; this lady came and said I had stolen a penknife - I said "I will go back."

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

929.
SARAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 4 lbs. of beef, value 2s. , the goods of
Charles Baker
.

CHARLES BAKER. I am a butcher . On the 10th of April a person told my man a woman had taken this beef from the shop; I had seen it about ten minutes before - the man brought the prisoner back, and she had my beef; I said to my man, "This is the woman I told you to take care of."

ANN BALLIS
. I saw the prisoner take the beef from the shop, which she placed under her arm; she then took up another, took up her cloak at the corner, and laid that one down - I told the man, and he took her.

ADAM McDONNELL
. I was on duty in Tottenham-court-road
, and saw the man with the prisoner; I took her with the beef under her arm - she would not state where she lived.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Transported for Seven Years .

930.
JOHN SKENNELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 2 shillings , the monies of
James White
.

JAMES WHITE. I keep a shop in Bedfordbury
. On the 10th of April, about six o'clock in the evening, I missed six half-crowns from my till - I could not imagine which way they went, as I could find no vacancy; the prisoner and two or three lads came in repeatedly, and that afternoon I marked some shillings; the prisoner took two of them from the till - my son told me he saw his hand go into the till, and gave me a hint about the prisoner, who ran out - I pursued; he ran, and threw the two shillings over his hand at me - I ran, and stopped him; a young man took up the two shillings, and gave them to me - they were two of my marked shillings; I do not know who took them up - he had not run above forty or fifty yards when he threw down the two shillings.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. You say the young man picked up the money? A. Yes - I did not see him pick it up; the prisoner's father states that he is between nine and ten years old - there was a little boy he brought with him; I did not see him take them - no one was near the till but him - on the Saturday night he came for a halfpenny pencil; he brought a lad to ask for the pencil, while he put his hand under the counter into the till - I believe the prisoner had 3d. to buy a pound of flour at the next door; he had no flour-bag with him, but little bag with 3d. in it.

JURY. Q. What side of the counter is your till? A. It is next the window near the door - there is an opening at the end of the counter under it; there was a vacancy into which a lad could put his hand - he got into the dark corner; my counter is about ten feet long - this crevice is under the end of the counter; it was a long time before I couldfind it out - I lighted a candle three times, and was obliged to put it out again; I could not find it.

THOMAS CUSS
. I heard a noise, went out, and took the prisoner and the money - the prosecutor said that he threw it away, and a young man picked it up and gave it him; the prisoner cried very much, but did not say any thing - he had no bag.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you been an officer? A. Eight years; I have only sworn to what he told me - I was beadle of the parish, but I left it with a good character.

JAMES WHITE
. These are the shillings; I marked them with a few scratches with a knife.

JOHN WHITE
. I am the prosecutor's son. I was in the shop about ten o'clock in the morning of the 10th of April; I saw the prisoner go up towards the till, press against the counter, and feel as if feeling for the till - I suspected he had put his hand into the till, and told my father to take him; he ran off - my father ran and took him; I had discovered the crevice on the Saturday evening, which was so small that no man's hand could go into it - we did not miss money till that Saturday.
JURY. Q. Is the till at the top or the bottom of the counter? A. At the top - there has been a piece of board pulled away from the end of the counter, that confined the till.

COURT. Q. Did you try whether you could get any thing into the till? A. Not without stooping - it is under the counter; it is possible for a boy to get his hand in - the till is very long and comes up to the back of the counter; I saw the money was gone from the till - my father marked it.
Q. What is the depth of your till? A. Eight inches, and the opening about two inches.
Cross-examined. Q. And do you mean to say the boy could put his hand to the bottom of that till? A. I could nearly get my own hand in.
NOT GUILTY .

931.
MARY ANN ROGERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 1 gown, value 6d.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 1s. 3d., and 1 band-box, value 3d. , the goods of
John Gibbs Fox
.

JOHN GIBBS FOX. The prisoner was my servant . On the 13th of April I went out in the afternoon, and when I returned at six o'clock in the evening, my wife told me something was missing; I looked and missed these articles - the handkerchiefs were mine, and the gown my wife's; the prisoner had left my service while my wife was out - I found her the next day at No. 20, Wych-street, and charged her with taking the things; she said the property in her box was mine.

JOHN NORTHAGE
. I am an officer. I took this box and the prisoner in Wych-street - she told me she was induced to take them by a young man.
Prisoner's Defence. It was no such thing; I do not know any young man - I did not take the things myself.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

932.
JANE RENN
and
SARAH TOULMIN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 basket, value 1s. 10d., and 15 lbs. of potatoes, value 8d. , the goods of
Reuben Spark
.
It being the property of Reuben Spark and another, the prisoners were found NOT GUILTY .

933.
HENRY POWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of April , 5 pieces of wood, value 2s. , the goods of
William Fitze
.

JOHN TAYLOR
. I am a labourer, and live in Shepperton-place
. Mr. Fitze has been building two houses in that place - these boards were missed from there on the Sunday; I saw them safe that morning at half-past nine o'clock - we missed them about ten; I know nothing of the prisoner.

WILLIAM HOLLIS
. I am a cheesemonger, and live in Shepperton-place, New North-road. Last Sunday week I saw the prisoner watching about two empty houses - I saw him take this wood out of Mr. Fitze's house, and walk away with it; I followed and got an officer, who cried Stop thief! - he put down the wood and ran away; Miller took the wood, and Lovelock took him.
Prisoner. Q. Did you see me take it out of the house? you said you saw me pick it up? A. I saw it risingup outside of the house, and he took it away - I did not see him in the house.

JAMES MILLER
. I pursued the prisoner, and took him with these boards.

ROBERT LOVELOCK
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and stopped the prisoner; he said he picked the boards up in the road.

JOHN TAYLOR
. These boards were nailed up against the windows to keep the wet out, on the Saturday afternoon, and on the Sunday I saw them safe - I cannot say whether they were taken down, or thrown down.

Prisoner's Defence. I was going across the field, and saw these boards laying on the ground; I took them up, and heard Stop thief! called.
NOT GUILTY .

934.
MARY PORTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 60 yards of calico, value 30s. , the goods of
John Hughes
.

JOHN HUGHES. I am a linen-draper , and live in Chiswell-street
. On the 12th of April the prisoner took this calico, which was laying inside my door; I followed her, brought her back, and took it from her.

JOHN KELLY
. I took the prisoner, and have the property.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 39. -
Transported for Seven Years .

935.
WILLIAM PARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of April , 3 weights, value 3s. , the goods of
Theophilus Price Haddock
.

THEOPHILUS PRICE HADDOCK
. I live in Margaret-street, Hackney-fields
. I was in my kitchen in the afternoon, on the 2nd of April - I went into my shop, and saw the prisoner at the counter; he asked for a halfpenny worth of sugar - I asked if he had no more money, he said No; I said I would make him a half-penny worth; I took some paper to put it in, and missed my weights; I said."Where are my weights?" he said,

"I will go and get more money" - he ran out, I pursued him; he was stopped and brought back in ten minutes; the weights were found in the middle of the road; three were found exactly corresponding with those I lost.

FRANCIS CLARK
. I am a baker. I went out of Mr. Richardson's shop and saw the prisoner running; I went and took him a hundred yards from the prosecutor's shop; I saw nothing of the weights.

JOHN RICHARDSON
. Clark was in my mother's shop, I heard Stop! called - I went out and picked up three weights in the street; I gave them to Mr. Haddock.

ANN HADDOCK
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I saw Richardson pick up something; he brought me the weights.

ROBERT OVERDON
. I am a constable; he had nothing on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had a halfpenny in my pocket, but the gentleman did not feel in that pocket; I never took the weights.
GUILTY. Aged 13.

Judgment Respited
.

936.
ANN MARSHALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 1 coat, value 15s. , the goods of
William Coucher
.

WILLIAM COUCHER. I am a hairdresser , and live in Tabernacle-walk
. At half-past seven o'clock in the morning of the 14th of April I went to the parlour to light the fire -I thought I heard something come in; I turned, and saw a woman going out - I went into the shop and missed my coat from a peg; I went out, and saw the prisoner two doors from my house, with the coat; she said distress and poverty drove her to it - and she hoped I would not be hard with her; at the same time she was in a state of beastly intoxication.

THOMAS MANTON
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner; she had been drinking.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress; I met a person who gave me some liquor, which got into my head.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Two Months .

937.
MICHAEL McCREA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 1 candlestick, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Jesse Adkins
.

JESSE ADKINS. I am landlord of the Laurel, Camden-town
. My servant, Moore, came to me on the 20th of February - I went and missed a candlestick from the seat in the tap-room; the prisoner was there reading the newspaper - I went and rubbed him down; I felt something hard, and said, "What have you here?" - he said,"Nothing, Sir," - I opened his waistcoat, and found my candlestick.

JANE MOORE
. I missed the candlestick, and told my master.

ABRAHAM LORIMER
. I am an officer. I bring the candlestick - I found 4s. 3d. on the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I went into the tap-room - it was full of men; they said, "Hallo Pat!" and one of them hove the candlestick into my jacket.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Confined Three Months .

938.
CHARLES PRICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 1 tea-chest, value 18s. , the goods of
George Gairdner
.

GEORGE GAIRDNER. I am an upholsterer , and live in Tottenham-court-road
. This tea-chest was standing on a chest of drawers in my shop, on Saturday, the 10th of April - it was safe at nine o'clock in the morning when I left.

JOHN MURRAY
. I saw the prisoner near the shop; he went and sat on a sofa in front of the shop; he put his hand into the shop, took the tea-chest, put it under his jacket, and went off - I ran across; there was another man with the prisoner - I could not hear what they said; the other beckoned the prisoner and they turned down Howland-street - I did not lose sight of the prisoner.

WILLIAM GODFREY
. I saw the prisoner take the chest from the shop - he sat on the sofa, put his hand back, and took it; I followed and took him with it in his possession; he ran down Howland-street.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I received charge of the chest.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw that on the step of a door of a public-house - I took it up and asked if it belonged to them; then this gentleman said I must go with him.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

939.
JAMES McDERMOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 2 pairs of trousers, value 7s.; 1 coat, value 5s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 hat, value 3s.; 2 waistcoats, value 2s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 shawl, value 2s., the goods of
Michael Collins
; and I pair of trousers, value 4s.; 2 shirts, value 4s.; 1 gown, value 5s.; 3 handkerchiefs, value 3s.; and 1 towel, value 6d. , the goods of
John Tattersal
.

MICHAEL COLLINS
. I am a labourer. On the 29th of September I saw the prisoner at the Castle, in the Broadway
; he came and sat down close against me; my clothes were then in my box up stairs, as I lodged at that house - all the articles stated were in my box except my hat, and that was gone likewise, and an old hat left in its place which I knew was the prisoner's; the prisoner was gone when I missed them, and I have seen none of them since -Tattersal's things were in my box in my care.

Prisoner. Q. What intercourse with me had you, that you knew the hat was mine? A. Because you wore it on the watch with me, and you had it on that morning - I took particular notice of it; I could swear to it from all the hats I ever saw in my life - it was at nine o'clock when you were first in company with me that morning; afterwards two other men came in, and Johnson and they went to get their breakfasts, I believe.

JOHN WOODS
. On the 29th of September I was standing on the Broadway pavement, and saw the prisoner going from towards the house where Collins lodged to his own lodging, it was about half-past eleven o'clock; he had a very large bundle with him tied up in a red shawl, which I have seen Collins wear round his neck; I saw about his trousers a parcel, which appeared about the size of a man's arm, and part of a gown tail hung over his boot - he saw it as he knocked at the door, and tucked it in.
Prisoner. Q. Was not that the time you ought to have stopped such a man? Witness. I ought to have done it, and you are the man.
Prisoner. He is a man who ought not to be allowed to give evidence; he would come home at all hours of the night, and has a wife and child he is bringing up in a bad manner.

PHILIP ANDREWS
. I had a warrant against the prisoner on the 7th of April on another charge; on his examination at Bow-street I heard of this - I went to the Castle, and found Collins had removed; on Good Friday I went to his lodgings, where he gave me a list of what he had lost, and this letter which the prisoner had sent him - (read.)

Friend Collins. I met to-day Johnson, and he told me that I have done something wrong in your place, which if I have I am not conscious of so doing; however, he advised me to come to you, as he was going out of town for a few days, but you may depend on it you shall be satisfied, if I have done any mischief, before three o'clock on Monday next, and I have requested of Johnson to call on you when he comes to town, hoping this will satisfy you till then; I am living here in Camberwell with a pensioner of my own regiment, as I expect to receive prizemoney every day, and should I be so fortunate as to get it before Monday you shall hear from me, as I gave Johnson up my prizeticket this morning when I met him in St. Martin's-lane - he desired me to tell you of it, and to write this letter to you; I hope you will make yourself easy till you see him or me, between this and Monday. No more at present.
JAMES McDERMOTT
.
I hope you do not mean to hurt me till you see me.

Prisoner's Defence. I was drinking with Collins on account of the watch being broken up at the time; three or four more were in company with us; some time in the day he got tipsy, and left the company - I went to my own quarters in Westminster, and next day I went down to Chatham to draw some prize-money; in going I met Johnson, who told me Collins had been robbed, and had a suspicion I had done it; I wrote the letter, and stated as you have heard.

GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Seven Years .

940.
MARY KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 2 gowns, value 15s.; 1 frock, value 2s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 pinafore, value 1s. , the goods of
John Parks
.

SARAH PARKS
. I am the wife of
John Parks
- he lives in Somers'-town
. I lost these articles while I was out at work; I was sent for to the watch-house, and saw them there; I know nothing of the prisoner.

CHARLES DENNIS
. I am a silversmith. On Wednesday last I saw the prisoner watching some children at play at a door - I took notice of her; the children went a few doors off - the prisoner stepped into the prosecutor's house, and came out with these gowns in a basket, and these other things wrapped up in this pinafore - she began running; I asked one child whether she knew the prisoner- she said No; I pursued, and took her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she had come from Southampton in search of her daughter, who had been seduced, and that on going into the prosecutrix's house she was tempted to take the property, being without a shilling.
GUILTY. Aged 40.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury . -
Confined 1 Month .

941.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of February , 1 saw, value 4s., and 1 plane, value 4s. , the goods of
William Barton
.

WILLIAM BARTON. I am a carpenter . On the 22nd of February I worked till breakfast - I then went away, and left my saw and plane in a house in Kingsland-road - I had to go to another place; I came back next morning, and missed this saw and plane.

CHARLES WALLER
. I took the prisoner on the 22nd of February, in Hoxton New-town, with this plane.

EDMUND JULIUS SUTTON
. I am an apprentice to a pawnbroker. This saw was pawned on the 22nd of February, between seven and eight o'clock, by the prisoner, I believe.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I keep a stall in the street, and sell bells, locks, and other things - a man brought these things, and sold them to me for 5s.; I wanted some money, and pawned the saw - I then took the plane to another pawnbroker; I said it was my own, because I thought they would let me go.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .

942.
JOHN JACOBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of March , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 5s., and 1 hat, value 2s. , the goods of
John Robinson
.

JOHN ROBINSON
. I am a warehouseman . The prisoner and another man agreed to purchase these things for 30s.; the prisoner had but 5s. - he said, "I have a cheque, I will get the change, then come, and pay you;" I staid three hours - he did not come, and I told my servant not to let the things go without their paying the 25s.; I went out,and when I returned in the evening the prisoner was in custody - I live at Paddington
.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Was not that a pretty good sum? A. I do not know; it was not the other man who bought them, but the prisoner.

SOPHIA MEEKING
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. The prisoner and the other man came and looked over the things - the other man said, "Put them into your bag, and go;" the prisoner did so, the other pulled off his own coat, and fitted on another - he then said he had no money; I said I could not let the clothes go without - I pushed past the other man to go after the prisoner; the other prevented me, and held the gate to - I snatched it out of his hand, and ran to the top of the street; the prisoner set off running -I called Stop thief! he was pursued, and stopped - I never lost sight of him; I asked him to give me the clothes, and after some persuasion he gave me them, and followed me back to the house.

Cross-examined. Q. Then he might have ran away? A. No; the officer was close behind him - I was not present at the first bargain about them; I had not made a new bargain with the other man to let him have them for 25s., nor consented that the prisoner should have one of the articles for the 5s.; he was taken to the office - he was not allowed to offer the 25s. to me.

JABEZ WOOD
. I saw the witness running after the prisoner, and I stopped him - he did not say any thing.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Confined Three Months .

943.
WILLIAM COOKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of February , 1 pocket-book, value 5s., the goods of
Myer Nathan
, from his person .

MYER NATHAN
. I was in Hart-street, Covent-garden
, on the 15th of February, about four o'clock in the afternoon, and my pocket-book was extracted from my pocket- I turned round, and saw the prisoner running; I ran, and overtook him without losing sight of him - my pocketbook was handed to me from a cellar.

JOHN WILLIAM LLOYD
. I was going through Covent-garden market. I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner walking very close behind him - I heard the prosecutor cry Stop thief! I turned round, and the prisoner passed me - I made an attempt to catch him, but missed him; I saw the pocket-book then in his hand - he stooped down, and threw it into a cellar; I saw it handed up very shortly afterwards, and the prosecutor claimed it.
Prisoner. I leave it to the Jury.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
First Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

944.
HENRY WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February , 25 handkerchiefs, value 7l., 3 pairs of socks, value 2s., and 3 slippers, value 3s., the goods of
Margaret Dixon
and another, in the dwelling-house of
Mary Clark
and another .

ELIZABETH CLARK. I am Mary Clark's sister-in-law This happened at a public-house; the landlord died on the 5th of January -
Mary Clark
and his brother then had charge of the house, which is at Knightsbridge;
Mary Clark
's husband's name is Thomas - this property belonged to a person who had come in; I did not know it was stolen till afterwards.

JOHN ROYLE
. I am porter to
Margaret Dixon
, who lives in Cockspur-street. I had this property in a parcel to take to Sloane-street, on the 20th of February - I went into the Queen's Head, at Knightsbridge
, about two o'clock; I sat in the tap-room, nearly three quarters of an hour, with the parcel in my possession; I then went to the bar to speak to Clarke; I returned in two minutes, and the parcel was gone from the table where I had left it; I could hear nothing of it in the house - I cannot swear the prisoner was there; this was Saturday, and on the Tuesday I found it at a pawnbroker's.

WILLIAM CHURCH
. I am an officer. On the 22nd, in consequence of information, I went to the prisoner's lodgings, and found this duplicate under a chimney ornament, on the mantel-piece - he was then in custody; I knew he lodged there, for I saw him there on Sunday, the 21st, about another case - he wasthen with me.

JOHN KILLINGWORTH
. I am servant to Mr. Perkins, pawnbroker, of King's-road, Chelsea. I have a piece of silk pawned for 12s. on the 20th of February - I have a recollection of having seen the prisoner before, but am not quite positive he is the man; this duplicate is what I gave the person.

JOHN BUCKERIDGE
. I am in the employ of Bell and Co., silk-manufacturers. I know this silk to be their make, and believe it to be part of the goods sent to Dixon and Evans from our house; this invoice is what I sent with the goods.

JOHN ROYLE
. I have every reason to believe this to be part of the contents of the parcel; it had come for Bell and Co. - I lost the parcel about a quarter to three o'clock.

WILLIAM JAMES WILSON
. On Saturday, the 20th of February, the prisoner came to my master's shop in Piccadilly, for some black varnish - I am a brass-finisher; he took off his hat and took a piece of black silk from it- I asked him what it was for; he said for a handkerchief, and said I should have one for 5s. - I said I did not want it; he put it into his hat again - I knew him before; he was groom to Mr. Murray; it was about four o'clock.

Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Murray pays us at this public-house, and we run a weekly score there; I had a post of half-and-half there that day from our foreman - I had a black silk handkerchief in my hut, with two 1d. loaves and a piece of cheese; my hat fell off in the street - I picked up the handkerchief at the time.
GUILTY (of stealing only.) Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Justice Gaselee.

945.
ROBERT BENNETT
and
STEPHEN GRAVES
were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Hyndman
, about twelve o'clock on the night of the 21st of March , with intent to steal .

HENRY HYNDMAN. I am a Parliamentary agent , and live in Fludyer-street, Westminster
. Bennett came into my service as a clerk upwards of two years ago, and continued with me about five weeks.

JOSEPH CRANE
. I am a private constable of the Police.I was on duty in Fludyer-street on the 21st of March; I came off duty at twelve o'clock and observed a man in King-street, opposite Fludyer-street, and suspecting something was wrong, I walked to the end of King-street, and saw Cole, a Police-constable, in Charles-street - I told him, then came back, and saw the same man opposite Fludyer-street; I went up Fludyer-street on the right side, and in turning back again on the left hand I heard a noise in the prosecutor's area and saw the two prisoners in the area against the window - they saw me and drew back; I sprung my rattle - Graves came up; I asked what he did there - he said some person had thrown his hat over into the area; I said I must take him into custody - he used very rough language; we had a struggle for a few minutes - he called to the other prisoner to came up, but he did not, and with the assistance of another man we got him over the rails; in the mean time Cole came up - I charged him with the man in the area, and with assistance I took Graves to the watch-house; on his person I found a centrebit and a broken knife; I returned and found Bennett in Cole's custody.

JOHN COLE
. I am a Police-constable. I was on duty in Charles-street between twelve and one o'clock; I heard a noise in Fludyer-street, and proceeded to the spot; I found Crane tussling with Graves - Crane said he had come out of the area, and that there was another man in the area; I got a light, went down into the area, and found Bennett in the coal-hole - I asked him what he did there; he said some one had thrown his hat over - I found a skeleton-key on his person; in the corner where he was concealed there were several other keys, a chisel, a small crow-bar, the handle of a centre-bit, and several other skeleton-keys, which I gave up to Prior.
Cross-examined by Mr. HEATON. Q. He made no resistance? A. No, he seemed very much dejected.

JOSEPH PRIOR
. On Thursday night I went to Fludyer-street and found Bennett in custody; I went down the area - the kitchen window was lifted up, the pannel of the inside shutter bored throught with a centre-bit, and this piece and this small piece of the pannel were lying in the area; I fitted them into the pannel - I afterwards got the centre-bit and fitted it to some of the holes which had been bored; they agreed with it - after going inside the kitchen this blade of a knife was picked up, in my presence, by an officer, who is not here; I have compared it with the handle found upon Graves - they correspond exactly; the blade had been put through the hole, and I suppose snapped off, and fell inside - the impression on the shutter exactly corresponded with the crow-bar; the space between the inside of the window and the shutter I should suppose is not above two or three inches.
Cross-examined. Q. Is the kitchen under the house? A. Yes; the coal-hole is under the street - I did not find the centre-bit.
Prisoner Graves. Q. Where was the blade of the knife found? A. On the ledge under the window; I never said it was found on the table - I said I was near the table when it was picked up.

MR. HYNDMAN. I was in bed, and was alarmed by the Police knocking at my door; I believe I went to bed last- I make a practice of going round my house before I go to bed; the shutters were fastened with a bar - the window sash, I believe was not fastened; there is a catch to it, but it is so stiff it is useless - I have no doubt the sash was down that night, but I did not examine that; it is the cook's business to fasten the window - she is not here; it might have been partly up for what I know.

MR. HEATON. Q. At what hour did you go round the house? A. I think about half-past eleven o'clock - I had a light in my hand, and can say the shutters were whole; I distinctly remember there was no appearance of violence on the shutter.
NOT GUILTY .
The prisoners were detained, to be indicted for the misdemeanor.
Before Mr. Justice Park.

946.
ELIZABETH BOYD
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Mary Townsend
, on the 11th of April , and stealing 1 jacket, value 5s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 4s., and 1 pair of drawers, value 6d., the goods of
James Bills
; 1 shifts, value 6d., and 1 petticoat, value 6d., the goods of Mary Townsend .

JAMES BILLS. On Saturday night, the 10th of April, between twelve and one o'clock, I met
Mary Townsend
in Tothill-street, and went home with her; I saw her fasten the door - I staid all night with her; I awoke about half-past five o'clock, and missed my things - she was in bed.

MARY TOWNSEND. I live in Union-court, Orchard-street
. I took this man home, and locked the door - I only occupy one room; the landlady does not live in the house- I was awoke in the morning by Bills, and missed my shift and petticoat; I found the door open - Bills was making a noise about his things; Wilkins, the Policeman, came up to know if we had lost any thing - the staple of the lock was not forced; I do not know how it was opened.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not give me that bundle? A. No, on my oath I did not; you had not taken me home drunk on the Wednesday.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am a Policeman. About half-past five o'clock in the morning, I saw the prisoner cross Orchard-street with a bundle, and stopped her; she said they were her own things, and finding they were men's clothes I took her to the watch-house; I found the witnesses, who owned them - I lent the prosecutor a coat; he went to the watch-house, and claimed them in the prisoner's presence.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I met that woman at the end of the court, as I was going home; she asked me to be so kind as to take these things to my lodging, saying a man had left them with her, as he had no money - I had taken her home drunk a few days before, and she burst her door open.

MARY TOWNSEND
re-examined. It is false; I did not give it her - there were no marks of violence on my door, but I am positive I locked it.
JAMES BILLS. I did not examine the lock.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gaselee.

947.
MARY BELL
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Edward Roberts
, on the 14thof April , and stealing 1 apron, value 1s.; 1 cap, value 2s., and 1 pair of scissors, value 6d., his property .

SARAH ROBERTS
. I am the wife of
Edward Roberts
- we live in Nottingham-court
, on the second floor, and have but one room; the landlord does not live in the house. On the 14th of April I went out about half-past nine o'clock in the morning, and locked the door; I returned about half-past ten, and found it broken open - every thing was in confusion, and I missed these things; I had left the scissors on the table - I do not know the prisoner.

MARY KENNEDY
. I live in the kitchen of this house. I met the prisoner coming down stairs that morning, rather after half-past nine o'clock - she bade me good morning; I never saw her before, but am sure she is the woman- she went out, and I took no farther notice till Mrs. Roberts came in and missed her things; I then told her, and at half-past four o'clock I met the prisoner in Short's-gardens, and detained her.

SARAH ROBERTS. I went out with Kennedy to look for the prisoner, and at half-past four o'clock saw her, and gave her in charge to Wadey, who found my scissors on her, but nothing else - she said she had bought them for 1 1/2d., but I swear to them.

JAMES WADEY
. Roberts gave the prisoner into my charge in Short's-gardens, for breaking into her room and robbing her - she denied it; I found a pair of scissors on her, which she said she gave 1 1/2d. for - she did not say when.
SARAH ROBERTS. I had these scissors ground and new rivetted about a month ago, and had a point made to cut button-holes, as I do slop work; I have had them above two years.
Prisoner's Defence. I am sorry I bought them if they were stolen - if I had liberty I could bring the woman forward who I bought them of; I do not know her name, but know her by sight.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gaselee.

948.
THOMAS SKUCE
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Jane Hills
, on the 31st of March, and stealing 1 box, value 1d., and 6lbs. of iron, value 4d., her property .

JANE HILLS. I rent two rooms in Half Nichol-street, Bethnal-green
, and also hire a cellar - the landlord does not live in the house. On the 28th of March I saw this box of old iron in my cellar - the cellar is divided into two parts; I have the back part, the other is not used - my part was locked, but there is a hole from the front cellar which a boy could creep through from the yard; he could then open a door in my cellar, which is neither locked nor bolted; it is merely boards which form part of the partition.

GEORGE ALLCOCK. I was an officer when this occurred. I now live at Bethnal-green. On the 31st of March I was in Half Nichol-street about half-past eight o'clock, and saw a boy coming along with something under his arm; I went over and found it was this box covered over - in consequence of what he told me, I went to the next house to the prosecutrix, where the prisoner's mother lives, and found the prisoner there; I asked if he gave his brother that box to sell - he voluntarily said that he did; I asked where he got it - he said out of the prosecutrix's house; he is older than his brother who I had met with the box; it contains old iron, and is worth 5d.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it in my mother's cellar.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY (of stealing only.) Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.
First London Jury - Before Mr. Recorder.

949.
JOHN CARLISLE
was indicted for
unlawfully procuring 12 counterfeit shillings, with intent to utter the same .
MESSRS. SCARLETT and ELLIS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE STARR. I keep the Cross Keys public-house, Wood-street, Cheapside. On the 6th of March, about seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came in and asked for a glass of spruce and the newspaper - I gave him the spruce, and directed him to the coffee-room to read the paper; he gave me a shilling in payment, I gave him a sixpence and 4d. - I afterwards found it was a bad shilling; he was then gone - I thought he was in the coffee-room, but he had not gone there at all; I threw the shilling, into the fire, and it melted down like lead almost immediately - on Saturday, the 13th of March, he came about the same hour, and asked for a glass of spruce and the newspaper; I left my man to serve him - I recognized him and said, "You are the very man who gave me the bad shilling last week;" he then offered me a good one for it - he had not paid me any thing that night; I called in the constable who took him - he paid a good half-crown for what he had, and as the constable took him into the room he dropped a shilling, which I marked and gave to Earl, observing that it was a bad one; I am certain it dropped from him.

FRANCIS EARL
. I am a constable of Cripplegate. I received the prisoner in charge about seven o'clock in the evening - as I took him from the bar to the parlour, to search him more conveniently, a shilling dropped on the ground; I have every reason to believe it fell from him -I found in his waistcoat pocket twelve counterfeit shillings and four good sixpences, wrapped in a piece of rag and then in paper.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of the Mint. The shilling produced is counterfeit, it is Britannia metal, not worth a farthing; the twelve others are also counterfeit, and cast in the same mould - Britannia metal weighs rather more than one-fourth less than silver.
The prisoner pleaded distress.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Months .

950.
JAMES LANE
and
WILLIAM JOHNSON
were
indicted for a misdemeanor .
NOT GUILTY .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, APRIL 21.
Fifth Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

951.
JAMES LEE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of April , 1 gown, value 3s., and 1 shawl, value 2s. , the goods of
Eleanor Lee
, widow ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Confined One Month .

952.
WILLIAM ARNOLD
was
indicted for embezzlement ; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . -
Whipped and Discharged.

953.
THOMAS HACKWELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 5 sovereigns, and 15 shillings , the monies of
William Dowson
.

WILLIAM DOWSON
. I am a sadler . The prisoner lodged in my house - my daughter gave him a cheque for 5l. 15s. on the 11th of March, 1829, to get the money; he did not bring the money.

JEMIMA DOWSON
. I gave the prisoner this cheque(read, drawn by D. Fletcher, on Messrs, Gillespie for 5l. 15s.) - I gave it to him to be at Messrs. Gillespie's by ten o'clock; I told him if he would go, and come back directly, I would give him something to get a breakfast- he did not come back; I did not see him again till last March - his wife was out at the time; he went away with his child - she returned in a short time, took all their things, and went away.

WILLIAM COCKERILL
. I was at Messrs. Gillespie's when the cheque was paid - I entered it in the book, but I cannot tell who had it; it was paid on the day it is entered - Mr. Dowson came in the afternoon, and asked if we had paid the money; it had been paid two hours before.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. If you had not looked at the book, would you have remembered any thing about it? A. I distinctly remember the payment, but not the person; I looked at the back to see if it was entered - Mr. Gillespie asked me the question, and mentioned the name of Dowson; I cannot say whether it was a man or woman received it.

COURT. Q. Can you be sure whether the person who complained that the money had not been paid, was the person who presented it? A. My impression is that it was not, but I cannot be positive - it was paid in five sovereigns, but whether the silver was in shillings or halfcrowns I do not know; we keep sovereigns exclusively for the purpose of paying these orders, and never pay notes.
Q. But if I wanted a 5l. note to send in a letter, you would accommodate me with it? A. It is a very unusual thing; I never knew it done.

JURY to
WILLIAM DOWSON
. Q. What lodging had the prisoner of you? A. A ready furnished room down the yard; there were seven or eight weeks' rent due at this time.

GUILTY . Aged 39. -
Confined Six Months .

954.
PHILIP HUTCHINSON
was
indicted for bigamy .

GEORGE JACKSON GREEN
. I saw the prisoner married to a person of the name of Stubbs, about twelve years ago, at Bromley St. Leonard's, but the clerk is not here; I was sexton and am so still -
James Brand
was also present, but he is dead; there are no other witnesses here.
NOT GUILTY .

955.
JOHN GRIMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of March , 1 ham, value 7s. , the goods of
Thomas Courtney
.

THOMAS COURTNEY. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Drury-lane
. On the 20th of March I lost a ham, about half-past eleven o'clock at night - I did not see it taken, but the Policeman brought it back, and I believe it to be mine; I had had it in my hand twice that day - I do not see any difference between this and mine; it is the same weight and size.

JOHN RAWLEY
. I stopped the prisoner on suspicion, three or four hundred yards from the shop, with this ham under his arm - I asked where he got it; he said at a shop leading to Clare-market, which is the prosecutor's - I lodged him in the watch-house, and took the ham to the shop; he said he bought it at 5 1/2d. per lb., and it weighed 10 1/4lbs., but it weighs 12 1/4lbs. - he was going from the shop.
Prisoner. I said 6d. per pound.
THOMAS COURTNEY. It would have been 7d. per pound.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw this ham and asked the price - they said 7d. per pound; I said I would give 6d. for the whole, and it was weighed to me - it weighed 10 1/2lbs., and I gave 5s. 1 1/2d. for it.
JURY to JOHN RAWLEY. Q. Had he any money on him? A. He stated that he had none, but I believe he was not searched.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

956.
JOHN GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 8 live tame fowls, price 16s., and I live tame duck, price 4s. , the property of
Edward Sadler
.

ROBERT BATEMAN
. I am a Police-officer. On the 7th of April, at a quarter before five o'clock in the morning, I met the prisoner on Stepney-green, with this duck wrapped up in a smock frock - I asked what he had got; he told me nothing - I found this duck, and then he said he had bought it half an hour before, of a sailor for 1s. 6d.; I found nothing else on him.

MARY ANN BRUNEGAS
. Mr. Edward Sadler lives at Laytonstone
- I take care of his place, and had the fowls and duck in a hen-house; they were all safe and locked up on the 6th of April, and when I got up the next morning they were all gone - I missed eight fowls and this Muscovy duck; I know nothing of the prisoner - they had taken the tiles off, and got in at the top of the house; I know this duck very well, and he knows me.
Prisoner's Defence. I had it tied up in my old smockfrock - I said it was a Muscovy duck I gave 1s. 6d. for.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .

957.
HENRY BULL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
John Williams
, from his person .

WILLIAM WATERER
. On the 4th of April I was in Catherine-street
, and saw a gentleman, who gave his name as
John Williams
, at the watch-house, but it was a false address; he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

958.
HENRY BULL
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
William Crampton
.

WILLIAM CRAMPTON. I am a servant , and was in Wych-street
on the 4th of April, at four o'clock in the afternoon; I had a handkerchief in my right-hand coat pocket - I felt a pull, looked over my shoulder, and saw the prisoner with it - he was taken into custody directly with it.

EVAN OWEN
. I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor inWych-street; I did not see the prisoner do anything; but the prosecutor called me, and gave him into my charge with this handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Life .

959.
ELIZABETH GOODALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of April , 3 sovereigns, and 1 half-sovereign, the monies of
Samuel Stewart
, from his person .

SAMUEL STEWART
, I am an Excise-officer . I was in Shadwell High-street
between one and two o'clock in the morning of the 10th of April - I was out on business; the prisoner accosted me in the street, and asked me to go home with her - I refused, and desired her to go about her business; she caught hold of my right arm, put her hand into my right-hand waistcoat pocket, and took out three sovereigns and a half, which I had had safe five minutes before she came up to me - I had no hole in the pocket; there was another woman in company, who walked on my left-hand side - she did not take any thing from me; the prisoner came up in about ten minutes, and took my arm - I did not stop at all with them, and I swear the prisoner is the woman who took my money; she was taken in three or four minutes, but nothing was found on her - I had been drinking a glass, but was as sober as I am now; I had been to Shadwell High-street, and was going home sober.
Prisoner. He neither knew when, nor where, nor how he lost his money. Witness. Yes, I do; the Policeman was near, and I called him to follow her.

DAVID LOVICK
. I am a Police-officer. The prosecutor accused this woman of robbing him of three sovereigns and a half - he was not sober, but appeared to know what he was about; I pursued the prisoner - she had just turned round Cannon-street; I called her, and she turned back - I took her in front of the prosecutor, and found on her 1s. 6 1/2d.; there was another woman with the prosecutor- I saw them all three standing together near the watering-house; I went up to Bluegate-fields, dispersed some girls, and when I returned the prosecutor stated the case to me - I took the prisoner; the prosecutor was reeling about, but was able to answer questions.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the man with a woman holding his arm - the woman said, "Come," and I went with them to the night-house; he called for a quartern of gin; he said, "I will go inside" - I bade him good night, crossed the road, and went down Cannon-street, when the officer took me.
NOT GUILTY .

960.
WILLIAM FLOWER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Harman
, from his person .

ROBERT HARMAN. On the 1st of March, between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, I was in Coventry-street Haymarket
; I had a handkerchief in my pocket - I did not feel any thing, but a gentleman told me my pocket was picked; I turned, saw the prisoner in his hand, and my handkerchief at his feet.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Is that gentleman here? A. Yes; this is the handkerchief - I had not seen the prisoner before.

THOMAS HOLLINS
. I was in the street, and saw the prisoner and other following the gentleman - I watched them, and saw the prisoner pick his pocket; I collared him, and the gentleman turned and took him.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you swear you saw him take it out of the pocket? A. Yes; the others were behind him - I do not know what became of them.(Property produced and sworn to.)
