Prisoner's Defence. This gentleman says there were three of us, but there was only one more beside me; I saw another boy take it - I was going to tell the gentleman, when I was accused of it.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Life .

961.
PETER STUBBS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of February , 156 finger plates, value 5l., and 55 locks, value 4l., the goods of
Thomas Frith
; and that he had been previously convicted of felony .
MR. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

JONATHAN MOORE
. I am a servant to Mr. Thomas Frith; he is a block ironmonger , and lives in High Holborn
. On the 22nd of February the prisoner came for a pair of butt hinges - he told me to make the holes larger; he was walking about the shop - I watched him, and saw him go to the partition where the finger-plates were kept in parcels, which are marked; he took a parcel, and put it under his apron - my master's son was in the shop; we went to him, found the plates under his arm, and my master's son took them from him - I saw him take them from the partition; we have lost a great many of these articles.
Prisoner. He found nothing on me at all. Witness. Yes, I did, under his apron.

BENJAMIN BIRDSEYE REEVE
. I am the pawnbroker. I have a great number of plates, pawned by the prisoner at different times.

THOMAS JOHN BARNETT
FRITH. I am the prosecutor's son. I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner stoop down, and take the parcel - he passed it from his right hand to his left; I went, and took it from him - this is it; our mark is on the paper.
Prisoner's Defence. When I went to the place, where these parcels were, I took up one of them, and the witness said, "He had got a parcel in his hand," and called his father down stairs. GUILTY.

MATTHEW CARTER
. I produce a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner, by the name of
Peter Stokes
, on the 9th of July, in the 9th year of his Majesty's reign; he was sentenced to three months imprisonment - I took him, and know he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 57. -
Transported for Life .

962.
PETER ANDERSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of March , 9 chisels, value 2s., and 1 mallet, value 1s., the goods of
Harker Cansick
, his master .

HARKER CANSICK. I am a stone-mason . The prisoner was in my employ, and I paid him once a week - I had been losing a number of tools for a long time; I knew where he lived, went, and found this mallet and these chisels, which I know are mine, and which I had missed.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

963.
JAMES WATSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of March , 8 books, value 4s., the goods of
William Myers
, his master .

WILLIAM MYERS
. I am bookseller and stationer , andlive in the Commercial-road
- the prisoner was my apprentice for about twelve months; these books were found in his possession - he was attempting to sell them; I know they are mine - they are Sunday-school poems.

GEORGE DEVERELL
. I am beadle of Shadwell. On the morning of the 10th of March, I was going along High-street, Shadwell, and saw the prisoner with something under his jacket - I went into the shop he came out of, and found he had been offering books for sale; I then went to an opposite house and looked through the window - I watched him for some time, and saw him go into a shop; I sent a person, and he was brought to me - he said he was going to sell them for his mother, who had a stock of them, and he was selling some for a breakfast; I took him to the watch-house, and sent for the prosecutor.
Prisoner. My master used to go and stay out all hours of the night; he kept me at home at work on Sunday, instead of going to church, and gave me no money.

WILLIAM MYERS
. I gave him money to go and see his mother, and he never went - I used to send him to church every Sunday with my sons.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Whipped and Discharged.

964.
JAMES FRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of January , 11 sovereigns, the monies of
John Meredith
, his master .
JOHN MEREDITH. The prisoner was my servant . On the 2nd of January my wife sent him with eleven sovereigns to my brother.

WILLIAM MEREDITH
. The prisoner came and brought me eleven sovereigns in a paper parcel; I saw the parcel, but not the money - I told him to take it back and to tell my brother I was not going in the City to-day, and he had better pay it himself.

Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. Then he delivered you a parcel, which you suppose contained the money, and as far as that went, completed his errand? A. Yes; I did not take it out of his hand - I went before the Magistrate; I heard what the prisoner said - I think it was taken down in writing; I did not say I would save his neck, but would transport him for life - I might say he deserved transporation.

MARY ANN MEREDITH
. I am the prosecutor's wife. I put eleven sovereigns into a silk purse, tied that in a brown paper, and sent the prisoner to William Meredith - I told him to say I was very unwell, or I would have brought it myself; I never saw him again till I saw him in a green-grocer's shop, in East-street, on the 26th of March, and had him taken.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go to his mother's? A. Yes; he had been there, but was out - I have never seen the money.
Prisoner. As I was returning I got into a crowd; my pocket was picked, and I was ashamed to return.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

965.
WILLIAM HILLIER PERRING
was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of February , 2 quarts of wine, value 8s.; 1 quart of rum, value 3s., and 3 bottles, value 6d. , the goods of
Robert Brown
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

ROBERT BROWN
. I keep the Berwick Arms, at the corner of Castle-street, Oxford-street
. About Christmas my cellar was under repair; I employed Godfrey, and he employed the prisoner, who I believe is his son-in-law - the door was taken off and repaired by the prisoner; in that cellar there was wine to a considerable amount - it is the inner cellar; it opens into the spirit cellar - I have examined the partition between the two cellars, and find a hole cut on one side of the post, for a bottle to pass and re-pass, and a mark where some one's finger had been cut and bled; I never allowed the prisoner to go to my cellar after the job was over - he never asked; on Saturday night, the 27th of February, my servant gave me information, and I had the prisoner taken on the 1st of March.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When did you find the blood? A. On the Monday morning, when I found three bottles broken, and lying in the cellar; I do not know how long it had been there - the prisoner was taken on the same morning; I did not order his hands and wrists to be searched - the officer mentioned the blood to me.

HANNAH HOARE
. I am the prosecutor's servant, On the Saturday I saw the prisoner come from the cellar - I followed him up stairs into the tap-room, where he had been in the whole of the day; I do not think he had been at work for a day or two.

WILLIAM TAYLOR
. I am a porter and chairman. On the 27th of February I was with the prisoner at the prosecutor's house, waiting to be paid; my father and other persons were there - the prisoner beckoned me out, I went out of the room: he said, "Don't take any notice, but it is my birth-day; and if you will go with me I will give you a glass of wine;" I said, "We had better go back, and pay that one pot between us;" he said we should not be five minutes: I went with him up to a house, in Castle-court, where Lousia Lawrence lodges - when we got there, he took a bottle of wine out of his pocket, and we drank it; I think I had two glasses: he then pulled out a bottle of rum - Lousia's mother said, "This won't do:" the prisoner and I had a glass a piece; I do not think there was much drank - the bottle and the rest of it was left there: we then went to Mr. Brown's, and paid a pint a piece towards the pot we had - I thought I had been treated enough and did not expect to have a second edition of it; but when we were coming out: he said, "I have another bottle of wine at home, suppose we drink it at your lodging" - we went to his father-in-law's to get it: I did not go in, but he did - we went to Mr. Brown's to get a light: he then went to a fishmonger's-shop, and he served out the wine among a number of people there; we then went home and drank the rest.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see him take any wine from Mr. Brown's? A. No; Godfrey is a carpenter - he bore a fair honest character.

COURT. Q. How long have you known him? A. I suppose nine or ten years; he has borne a good character as a tradesman, as far as I know - there was one time I heard he had been here, but I was not in Court, and did not know much of him then: I have only heard of it since this business.

LOUSIA LAWRENCE
. The prisoner came to my lodging on the 27th of February, and brought a bottle with wine and a bottle with about half a pint of rum in it; we drank the wine amongst us, and I believe two glasses of rumwere drank by Taylor and him - there was but a little left; the officer came and asked for two bottles: my mother gave him the bottles, they were clean.

Cross-examined. Q. Would you venture to swear they were the two bottles the prisoner brought? A. No; the prisoner and the witness were very much in liquor - the bottle was not one third full of rum; I suppose it was between a pint and a quart.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Were they not what are commonly called quart bottles? A. I cannot answer.

COURT. Q. What is your age? A. Twenty-one; I am a waistcoat-maker - I cannot tell whether both the bottles were alike; I drank part of their contents - it was poured into a glass: it was candle-light - it was dark coloured wine; I am not acquainted with wine - there was rum, not gin in the other bottle.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I took the prisoner at his father's, in company with Whaley; and in his righthand pocket I found this key; I took him to Mr. Brown's, and left him in the parlour while I went down - I found this key would open the spirit-cellar door rather better than Mr. Brown's key would; this is the key - I went to Lawrence's lodgings with Taylor; I asked if he had left any wine or bottles there - Lawrence's mother put her hand out of the window and gave me them out of a gutter; they had been fresh washed: I did not search the lodging; I had been to Taylor's lodgings, and he gave me a bottle which had contained Port wine.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say his father-in-law, Godfrey had given it him? A. No. I saw the blood in the cellar; it might have been there a day or two - I examined the prisoner's arms and wrists, but found no cut on them.

JURY to
ROBERT BROWN
. Q. Was it blood or Port wine? A. Having been brought up a butcher I think I am too good a judge of blood to be deceived; I should think I have not less than 50l. worth of wine and spirits: I think it possible there might be another engaged in it.

Prisoner's Defence. I never entered the place with the key in my pocket; I was not certain that it would have fitted it - it is not reasonable that I should have returned to the prosecutor's house if I had robbed him.
NOT GUILTY .

966.
MARY WARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 1 sheet, value 1s.; 2 pinafores, value 1s.; 1 bolster, value 4s. 5d.; 2 pairs of boots, value 12s.; 2 shirts, value 2s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 1s. 6d.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 shawl, value 1s.; 1 frock, value 1s., and 1 cap, value 1s., the goods of
Joshua Flight
, her master .
JOSHUA FLIGHT. I am bar-man at a wine-vaults . The prisoner was servant to me for twelve months; she left me without notice, and I missed this property.

GEORGE LANCASTER
. I am servant to a pawnbroker in Goswell-road. I have a number of these articles pawned by the prisoner.

JOSEPH JOHN
GOODGE. I have three pinafores and a frock, pawned by the prisoner, I believe; she is in the habit of coming to the shop.

WILLIAM CRABB
. I took the prisoner, and found the duplicates on her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutor engaged her as housekeeper, to take the charge of four children, but was too poor to supply them with the common necessaries or pay her wages; that she had pledged the articles to procure his children food.

JOSHUA FLIGHT re-examined. Q. Have you been in such a state of indigence that you have employed her to pawn your property, or allowed her to do it? A. No - I allowed her money as a housekeeper; she has pawned her own property - I do not owe her any thing; I passed my word at a tally-shop, and a man has come to me for it.
Four witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 49.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Confined One Month .

967.
SAMUEL PENTLAND
was
indicted for bigamy .
The witnesses were not in attendance.
NOT GUILTY .

968.
JAMES DACEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
William Stevens
, from his person; and that he had been previously convicted of felony .

WILLIAM STEVENS. I am in the service of Mrs. Hitchins, Beaufort-buildings, Strand. I had a handkerchief in my pocket; a man ran against me and said I had been robbed - I felt and my handkerchief was gone; in about half a minute or a minute a young man collared the prisoner with my handkerchief.

JOHN BRUNDLEY
. The prisoner was given into my custody by Mr. Murray; this is the handkerchief.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN MURRAY
. I saw the prisoner and another person with him; the prisoner took the handkerchief from the pocket - I sent a young man to tell the prosecutor; I took the prisoner who ran into the passage of a coffee shop.
GUILTY.

ABRAHAM HAINES
. I have a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner on the 11th of June, in the 10th year of his present Majesty's reign; I was a witness on the trial - he is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Life .

969.
ALEXANDER FOX
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of March , 4lbs. weight of beef, value 1s. 8d., the goods of
Frederick William Hilder
; and that he had been before convicted of felony .

FREDERICK WILLIAM HILDER
. I am a butcher . On the evening of the 6th of March, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was just going into the shop hanging up the meat; the prisoner walked by and took a piece of beef off the board - he laid a handkerchief on it and took it; I followed him about twenty yards, and gave charge of him.

JOHN DANE
. I took the prisoner into custody.
Prisoner's Defence. A man said "I want you," took me to the shop, and said I had stolen a piece of beef; I did not know what he wanted me for. GUILTY.

RICHARD MILLIN
. I have a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner on the 15th of January, in the ninth year of his present Majesty's reign; I gave evidence - he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Life .

970.
THOMAS PHENY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of February , 2 lbs. weight of soap, value 14d., the goods of
Thomas Winmill
; and that he had before been convicted of felony .

THOMAS WINMILL. I am a grocer , and live in Carnaby-street
. I was out at the time this happened.

JOHN MATTHEWS
. I live in Marlborough-court, near the prosecutor's; I saw the prisoner near his shop, with three other persons - the prisoner went and asked for one halfpenny worth of Spanish liquorice, while one of the others took the soap from the counter; the prisoner then took the soap - I gave an alarm, and he was taken in Maddox-street, with the soap, which he dropped.

WILLIAM DODD
. I saw the prisoner put the soap under his coat, as I was standing in Lowndes-court; we went and asked at the prosecutor's shop, if they had lost any thing - they said Yes, a piece of soap; we pursued the prisoner and met an officer, who took him.

JOHN ANDERSON
. I took the prisoner - this is the soap.
Prisoner's Defence. I was standing still when they took me; the soap was on before me. I went to buy the Spanish liquorice, and one of the boys took the soap; I did not. GUILTY.

EDWARD BURRIDGE
. I have a certificate of the conviction of the prisoner on the 29th of October - I was present, and know he is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Life .

971.
JAMES HOBSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April
, 4 cruets, value 18d., and 1 cruet-stand, value 6d. ; the goods of
Thomas Pickett Hemmings
; and
JOHN DAVIS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the same day, the same goods, well-knowing them to have been stolen .

EDWARD FRY
. I know the shop of Mr. Thomas Pickett Hemmings, in High-street, St. Giles'
. About ten o'clock, in the evening, on the 6th of April, I saw Hobson take the cruet-frame and four bottles from a shelf in the shop, just inside; he ran away - I gave an alarm; I went to look after him, but could not see him; I did not know him before.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. This was ten o'clock at night? A. Yes, the gas was alight; I saw his face - he made off in a short time: I was close to him.

THOMAS HOBBS
. On the 7th of April I was going on duty - I saw Davis with something under his coat, and Hobson by his side; I said, "What have you got there?" he said, "This, and this boy gave it to me" - they both said they were going to sell it; Hobson said another boy gave it to him - I took the other boy by his description, but he was acquitted by the Magistrate.
Cross-examined. Q. And he told you where he could be found? A. Yes, he said he had a shiny hat on, and I found him.

ELIZA HEMMINGS
. I am the wife of the prosecutor. The witness came and told me of this; I pursued the boy, but could not find him.

HOBSON -
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Confined Three Months .

DAVIS -
NOT GUILTY .

972.
ELIZA HARRIS
was indicted for that
she, on the 5th of March ,
Ellen Bonsey
, a child of
Robert Bonsey
and Lydia
, his wife , under the age of ten years, to wit, of the age of two years, feloniously by force, did take and carry away, with intent to deprive the said
Robert Bonsey
and Lydia, his wife, of the possession of the said child, by concealing and detaining the said child from them ; against the Statute, &c.
2nd COUNT, like the first, only substituting the words"by fraud," instead of force.

3rd COUNT, like the first, only with intent to steal certain articles of apparel about the person of the said child, to wit, 1 pinafore, value 3d.; 1 frock, value 4d.; 1 hat, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 2d.; 1 shift, value 2d., and 1 pair of boots, value 4d., the goods of the said Robert Bonsey.
4th COUNT, like the third, only stating it to be by fraud, instead of by force, &c.

ROBERT BONSEY. I am the husband of
Lydia Bonsey
- this little child is my daughter; she was two years old on the 25th of last January - her name is Ellen; we live in George-court, Strand
. On the 5th of March I saw my child playing near the door as near seven o'clock as could be; I just wiped my fingers, ran out, and the child was gone - I ran out, and made inquiries till half-past four o'clock on the Sunday; this was on the Friday- I found her at the refuge for the houseless poor.
LYDIA BONSEY. I was out at the time, and when I came home I heard the child was gone - I made every inquiry, but did not hear of her till Sunday.

HENRY PARDOE
. I am a Police-constable. On the 7th of March I saw the prisoner in Middle-row, St. Giles', at half-past one o'clock in the morning; she was sitting down with this child, and I said, "What do you do here, my good woman? why don't you go home?" she said, "I have no home;" I said, "I can take you to the refuge;" I took her there, and the superintendent would not take her in, as she had been there seven days, and was discharged for improper conduct; I had asked her if this was her child, and she said it was - I then asked her what she had done with the child while she was there; she said she had put it out at No. 22, Duck-lane, Westminster - I asked how she could pay for it; she said, by a few halfpence at a time - she had the child booked
Tommy Harris
; in taking her to the watch-house she said she had taken it from a door in the Strand, and I went to the place on the Monday, and found they had got the child.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

973.
CHARLES THOMAS WILLIAMS
was indicted for that
he, on the 10th of April , feloniously did cut, break, and destroy 10 trees, that is to say, 4 cherrytrees, 4 plum-trees, and 2 apple-trees, value 10l., then standing and growing, the property of and belonging to
Jane Flint
, whereby the amount of injury done to the said Jane Flint, exceeded the sum of 5l., that is to say, amounted to the sum of 10l. ; against the Statute, &c.
2nd COUNT, like the first, only substituting the word"damage" instead of destroy.
3rd COUNT, for feloniously breaking and destroying in part, &c., like the first count.
4th COUNT, like the third, only stating that he did cut, break, and damage, instead of destroy.

JOHN BARKER
. I am son-in-law to
Jane Flint
- she is a widow ; I superintend her garden; she is a market-gardener , at Isleworth
. On Saturday evening,the 10th of April, I saw the trees in her garden all safe, between six, and seven o'clock, and the next morning, between five and six, I found four plum-trees and four cherry-trees had been broken down and destroyed; one pulled up, and the others destroyed - the branches were all off; they had been against a wall; I afterwards found two apple-trees were destroyed, which had been full of bloom - they had been all alive, and were worth more than 10l. - I saw some footmarks, and had suspicion of the prisoner, from some language which he had used to me on the Saturday night; Mrs. Flint had warned the prisoner off her ground, and I had told the foreman to warn him off - I keep the Phoenix public-house, and on the Saturday night the prisoner was there; he wanted to kick up a row with six or seven others, and I told him to go along; he came, put his fist in my face, and said,"D-n your eyes, you bl-y b-r, I will go down the garden, and destroy every bl-y tree you have got"- I therefore thought he was the person, I fetched the constable to the garden, and sent him to take him on suspicion; his right shoe was taken off, and fitted to the marks in the ground; they matched exactly - he was sent to the cage; we went on board the prisoner's barge, and found some brocoli, which fitted to the stumps left in the ground - they had tried to break into the house, and if they had they would have done much more mischief.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were there not two persons taken? A. Yes; one is here as a witness - the nails fitted exactly in the footmarks; it was the right shoe - I do not know how many nails there were; there might be twenty-four - there were six nail marks in the ground; the prisoner had been drinking, but he was not so drunk but he knew what he was going to do - he was not sober.

JACOB CROWTHER
. I am a constable. I went on board a barge, and found the prisoner, on Easter Sunday morning, about seven o'clock, with his companion, who is here; I took the prisoner into custody, he took off his shoe at the garden, and gave it me to fit to the impression on the ground - it fitted in the nail marks, and in the impression where there were no nails; it was fitted in the presence of half a dozen people - I found as much brocoli on board the barge as would tie up in a common sized handkerchief; I saw two of the heads fitted to the stumps, and they matched exactly.

CHARLES GARDNER
. I know the prisoner, and was with him in a barge on the river, on the Saturday evening - he told me he was going to break all the bl-y trees that Barker had got in his place; I went with him to the garden, pulled up a few brocoli, he broke the trees, and then we went on board the barge - we were not more than half an hour in the garden; he pulled up some strawberry plants - I took the brocoli on board.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I hope you were sober?" A. Yes - he was a little the worse for liquor; he did all the mischief, except taking up the brocoli - he made me go against my will to the garden, take up the brocoli, and take it on board the barge.

JOHN BARKER
re-examined. Q. Did they pull up the trees by the roots? A. This one was broken down, and the root nearly out of the ground - the whole of the trees were destroyed.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

974.
CATHERINE WOOD
,
ELIZABETH CARPENTER
and
MARY DILLON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April
, 1 jacket, value 1s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1s. , the goods of
Mary Bennett
.

MARY BENNETT
. I keep a clothes-shop , in Brook-street, Stepney
. On the 14th of April, about six o'clock, Carpenter came in, and asked for a pair of shoes - she had a child in her arms; I had seen her a number of times -I said I had no shoes; she said I had, and then Wood, who was quite intoxicated, and another person came in -I did not see Dillon to my knowledge; I was afraid of their doing some mischief, and I wished to get Wood out - the third person said she would get her out; they went out - Carpenter remained; I put my hand to her and said, "Come again by and by;" none of them bought any thing - I closed my door as I was going out, and the next morning I missed a jacket and a pair of trousers, which the officer has.

EMANUEL HARRIS
. I keep a clothes-shop. On the morning after this Carpenter and Dillon came to my house, both very drunk, with this jacket and trousers on their arms - I told them to go off, and they did; I have no doubt this is the jacket by the buttons.

JOHN DOUGLASS
. I apprehended Wood at her lodgings, on the morning of the 15th of April - and found this boy's dress there.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Wood's Defence, Carpenter had my child to nurse -I was at Greenwich fair on Sunday, Monday and Wednesday; I know not how the dress came in my place, but when Carpenter had words with her husband she used to make my place her own.

Carpenter's Defence. I do not remember being at Mrs. Bennett's: I might have been there, but I never saw the dress till I saw it at this woman's - I was intoxicated; I suppose I went to buy the shoes, but I do not know.

JOHN DOUGLASS
re-examined. Q. What distance do they live from each other? A. About fifty yards, in the same passage.

CARPENTER -
GUILTY . Aged 39.

WOOD -
NOT GUILTY .

DILLON -
NOT GUILTY .

975. THE SAID
ELIZABETH CARPENTER
and
MARY DILLON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of April
, 1 sheet, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Brown
.

MARY BROWN. I am the wife of
Thomas Brown
; he lives in Ratcliff-highway. I sent my little niece to the pawnbroker with two sheets and one blanket; one of the sheets is quite lost - I afterwards went to the pawnbroker, who gave me a description of Carpenter and Dillon; I went to Mr. Harris and said, "I had been robbed" - he said, "Of a sheet, Mrs. Brown?" I said, "Yes, how came you to know it?" he said, "Two women have been here drunk, and wanted to sell it;" I then went down a court and saw Carpenter looking out at a window - I said to her, "Have you seen my little girl?" she said Yes - I said"Have you taken any thing out of her basket?" she said, No - she came down, and I walked with her some time; at last she said she had had the sheet of Dillon; we went to Dillon, who said she had not had a sheet for months - I said if she would give it up, I would say no more about it.

EMANUEL HARRIS
. Carpenter and Dillon came to myhouse intoxicated - I would not let them in; Mrs. Brown came to me and said, "If you go down Brook-street, you will see a dark woman;" Dillon did not come into the shop.

JAMES MURPHY
. I took Carpenter, and asked her about the sheet which she had offered to Harris - she said it belonged to Dillon; they were both sitting drinking tea - I asked where it was; she said she would not tell me - on the way to the station Carpenter said if we could make up the money, she would not hurt us.

Carpenter's Defence. I went to the pawnbroker's, and the child stood back; there were many people - I took the child up, put the things out, and laid them on the table; they would not take my article in - I walked away; I had not another thing to pawn - the woman came and said I had robbed her child, but I had not; there were a great many people there, and I left the articles on the counter; I never was in prison in my life before.

CARPENTER -
GUILTY , Aged 39.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence .

DILLON -
NOT GUILTY .

976.
ELIZABETH TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of April , 1 sheet, value 10s., and 1 shawl, value 4s. , the goods of
Thomas Russell
.

SARAH RUSSELL
. I am the wife of
Thomas Russell
. The prisoner lodged at our house, in Westminster
, for nine days - she had only part of a bed; it was not mentioned whether it was to be taken by the night or not - she went away without giving me notice, she owed something; when she had been gone six or seven days I missed a sheet and a silk shawl.

WALTER TANNANT
. I am a pawnbroker, in the employ of Mr. Rochford. I have a sheet; I cannot say who pawned it.

ISAAC CUTHBERTSON
. I took the prisoner, and found eleven duplicates on her, one for this sheet, and this shawl I found at her sister's, No. 20, Great Barlow-street.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .

977.
WILLIAM TROTT
and
GEORGE JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of April , 60 penny pieces , the monies of
Henry Harben
and
William Larking
.

JAMES THOMAS HORNSBY. I am in the service of Henry Harben and
William Larking
, cheesemonger
s, Whitechapel
. In the afternoon of the 16th of April, the two prisoners came into the shop together and had something, but I do not remember what - there was 5s. worth of penny-pieces tied up in a brown paper on the counter; both the prisoners went near to it, and Jones took it up and moved it towards Trott, who took it and put it into his pocket; they paid me a shilling - I then walked round and took Trott, who took the paper out of his pocket and threw it behind a tub of butter; I left him in the counting-house and ran and took the other prisoner.
- I saw Jones come out with a piece of cheese in his hand; I then saw him with Hornsby, and took charge of him - these are the pennypieces; I marked them.

TROTT -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Confined Three Months .

978.
JOSEPH RAINES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March , 1 jacket, value 12s.; 1 waistcoat, value 7s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 10s.; 1 shirt, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
William Kating
, in a certain vessel on the navigable river Thames .
The prosecutor did not appear .
NOT GUILTY.

979.
PHILIP PHILLIPS
and
WILLIAM PHILLIPS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of April , 2 window sashes, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
Robert Warton
, being fixed to a certain building .

JOHN POWELL
. I am an officer. I went to the Crooked Billet, at the corner of King David-lane; I asked Philip Phillips whether the sashes he had there were his own - he said Yes; that he had received them from his master, pointto his brother William: I asked William where he got them - he said from his master in Fore-street, Limehouse; I said I should wish to see his master, and we went out to go there - in going along, I asked Philip Phillips if William had given them to him to carry; William said,"Carry be d-d, one is as bad as the other:" I took them to the station-house, and next day found a house with three pair of sashes gone - this pair fitted exactly.

ROBERT WARTON
. Powell showed me a pair of sashes, which I had lost with two other pairs, from a house of mine in Dorset-street, Commercial-road
- this pair fitted exactly; I had seen them about a month before - the prisoner had worked for me as carpenter, at that very house.

ANN WILLIS
. I saw a man going over the wall of this house, ten minutes before eleven o'clock; I asked where he was going - he said to repair the house, and I saw no more of him.
MR. WARTON. There was a wall six or seven feet high to get over; the sashes had been fixed.

P. PHILLIPS -
GUILTY . Aged 30.

W. PHILLIPS -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

980.
MARY MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of April , 1 jacket, value 10s. , the goods of
Charles Gray
.

CHARLES GRAY. I am a mariner , and was paid off; I left Portsmouth on Tuesday night, and got to town on Wednesday, the 14th of April. I met the prisoner and went home to sleep with her; I gave her 2s. 6d. for the bed - I was not quite sober; but I knew what I was about - she said, "Lie down my dear, and let me pull your jacket off;" I pull it off and put it under my head - I went to sleep and when I awoke the house was open, and my jacket gone; I went out to look for her, and where should I find her but in New Gravel-lane, or somewhere there about; I do not know whether there was any money in my jacket pocket, but I had treated her very handsome, and the landlady said I had; I gave 9d. towards the child's frock; when I saw the prisoner I said, "You are the person" - I caught hold of her; and said, "Go for an officer:""Come along (said she) and we will have half a pint" - we went on to the Duke of York; but I would not go in; five or six girls came round and snatched her from me - I did not see her any more that night, but I told the officer.

A. E. REYNOLDS. I live in High-street, Shadwell. Onthe 14th of April the prisoner brought this jacket to pawn; I asked if it was her own - she said No, she was sent by
John Gray
; - I took it of her.(Property produced and sworn to.)

CHARLES GRAY
re-examined. Q. How came she to know your name? A. It was on my trousers, we are forced to have it on board a man of war.

Prisoner's Defence. He came to the house where I was with another female; they went up stairs - he came down in half an hour, and said he had no more money; would I go and take his jacket - this is the truth, he said he would send to his landlady to come and redeem it; I asked his name, and he said Gray.

GEORGE PHILLIPS
. I met the prosecutor between ten and eleven o'clock on Wednesday night; he was not drunk - he said this woman had robbed him: I said at that time of night I could not find her - but he had better come to me next morning; he came - I went to several places, and could not find her: I took the landlady of the house, and said if I could not find the prisoner, I should detain her; she used every exertion, and we found the prisoner in the Match-walk - I went to Mr. Reynold's; and they said they had no such jacket - I went again and found it there.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

981.
FREDERICK BROOKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 blanket, value 9d.; 1 quilt, value 1s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; and 1 sheet, value 2s. , the goods of
Samuel Denby
.

SARAH DENBY. I am the wife of Samuel Denby. The prisoner had a furnished room in our house - I missed the articles stated, and had him taken on the 15th of April; I had let these articles to the prisoner.

JOSEPH BEAL
. I am an officer. I was sent for and took the prisoner - I found four duplicates of the articles, which were pawned; they were in a drawer, and he gave them to me.

HENRY ROBERT REDWOOD
. I am in the service of a pawnbroker - I gave these two duplicates to a person who pawned this blanket and pillow; these other two were written by a young man in our service.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. They would have been redeemed on the Saturday following - I had a job, and wanted 5s. worth of varnish.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .

982.
CHARLES DUNN
and
THOMAS WOODROFFE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of March , 1 sack, value 2s., and 280 lbs. weight of flour, value 48s. , the goods of
Edward Westrup
.

EDWARD WESTRUP
. I am a miller , and live at Bromley, in Middlesex
. The prisoners were in my employ on the 1st of March; Dunn was a carter , and Woodroffe a miller ; Mr. Kingsford went to the mill on the 1st of March, and said something - I sent for Dunn the next day, and asked how he came by a sack of flour which he had sold to Mr. Kingsford; he said he had not sold any, but afterwards he said, to tell the truth, he had it of a baker in Gray's Inn-lane - we immediately sent to Mr. Perry, who returned an answer with which we were satisfied; Dunn was gone then, but his wife sent him over to us on the Wednesday - I think I had some conversation with him, but did not threaten or promise him any thing; nor did Shelswell in my hearing.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. His wife sent him to you - do you not remember your father saying, in your presence, that if he would tell all the particulars nothing would be done to him? A. He did not in my presence - I was present when his wife said she would send him; nothing had passed between me and his wife - I was present when his wife said she would send him; nothing had passed between me and his wife - I do not know what induced her to send him, except she thought we should get him; my father had some conversation with his wife - I did not tell Dunn that if he would tell all the truth I would pardon him.
Q. Now you see his wife is here - did not your father tell her it would be better if he would come? A. Not in my hearing - my father officiates there, but the business is only mine.

COURT. Q. Did your father say to Dunn's wife, "If he comes and tells the truth he shall not suffer for it?" A. Not to my knowledge; I did not hear any thing of that kind - when Dunn came he said he had sold a sack to Kingsford for 48s., and that Woodroffe had 15s. of it; Meredith, another carter, had received part of it - he said he had sold various others to the amount of eight sacks altogether; he said he had given Perry a sack of flour to sell - I left Dunn in custody; Shelswell brought Woodroffe.

THOMAS SHELSWELL
. I am an officer. I was present when the prisoners were taken - I told Woodroffe I took him for being connected with others in robbing his employer of some flour; he said if I had a mind to hear what he had to say, he would tell the truth - I said he might do as he chose; he said he was coming to work and met Dunn, who gave him 15s., and told him that was his share of a sack of flour which had been sold, but he was not to say any thing about it; he considered it was a sack belonging to his master.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What flour it was, was not specified? A. No - I did not know who his employer was.

JOHN KINGSFORD
. On the 1st of March Dunn called on me with a sack of flour, and said he had been to Mr. Orton with five sacks, and he had not money enough to pay for more than four, and would I take the other; I said how much was it - he said 50s.; I said I would give him 47s. - he said he should lose 3s. by that; I gave him 48s.

THOMAS PRENDERGRASS
. I was with Shelswell when Dunn was taken - he began talking a great deal about selling one sack here, and another sack there; I said he could expect no mercy, I must take him before the Magistrate - he said he wished to act like an honest man, and that he had taken eight sacks in the whole.
Dunn received a good character.

DUNN -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Three Months .

WOODROFFE -
NOT GUILTY .

983.
CHARLES HURNDELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of March , 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 1handkerchief, value 6d., and 1 comb, value 2d. , the goods of
John McLachlan
.

CHARLES HIPKINS
. I am an officer. I saw the prosesecutor on the 25th of March, who said he had lost his clothes - I went to Brunswick-place, Commercial-road, with him; he asked if the prisoner was at home - his mother said No; he asked to see his bag, and these things were turned out of it - I went in search of the boy , and found him; I asked what he had done with the waistcoat, if he had pawned it - he said No - I took him to the station, and asked him again - then he said he had pawned it for 1s.; I went to the pawnbroker's, and found it, with this half handkerchief, which the prosecutor said had been in one when he had it - the prisoner then said he took it from the ship; the prosecutor is now gone to sea, but he saw the property and swore to it.

CHARLES WILLIAMSON
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 25th of March the prisoner pawned this waistcoat with me; the prosecutor saw it, and swore to it.
Prisoner's Defence. The comb that was found in my bag I had had three or four months - I bought it myself; the sailor said it was his.
GUILTY. Aged 14.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury .
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

984.
EDWARD HAMLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 1 till, value 1s., and 4 shillings , the property of
James Greig
.

SARAH SUTLE
. I am servant to James Greig; he is a baker . I was sitting in the parlour behind the shop, at half-past seven o'clock in the evening, and heard money chinking - I got up, and saw a boy run out with the till in his hand; I ran to the door, and called Stop thief! he set the till down four or five doors off, and ran away - the next witness brought him back; I had not seen his face -I saw no other boy; I saw him when the witness pursued him; the till was taken up, and brought to me - we could not tell whether any thing was missing from it.

WILLIAM MATTHEWS
. I was standing opposite the prosecutor's and saw the prisoner run from the shop with the till; he set it down four doors off - I took him about eight doors further, without losing sight of him.

GUILTY . Aged 11. -
Transported for Seven Years .

985.
JOHN BRANNOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of March . 1 lb. weight of sole leather, value 2s. , the goods of
John Giblett
.
JOHN GIBLETT. On the 18th of March I was out; my man gave me some information - I did not miss any leather, but here is some which I know to be mine.

JACKSON GIBLETT
. On the 18th of March the prisoner came to the shop - I saw him put part of this leather into a bag, which he laid on the counter; he then went on buying some other leather, which he paid for - he was going away; I said he had more leather, which he had not paid for - I put my hand on the bag, and these four pieces of leather were in it.

Prisoner. I went with a friend to buy two pairs of soles; he selected a pair, and paid for them - I said, "If you will pay for the three pairs, I will settle with you when the boots I have to sole for you are done." Witness. There was one pair paid for.

EDMUND NEWMAN
. I am a shopman. The prisoner came in with another person, and said I was to look out a pair of 1s. 2d. soles for this man; I showed him some at 1s. 2d., and 1s. 3d. - he said, "I don't think these are quite good enough," and while I turned to get a pair at 1s. 4d., he put these two pairs in his bag -
Jackson Giblett
came round, and asked if I knew these men; I said No - the other man paid 1s., and the prisoner paid 4d.; they were then going out, Giblett put his hand on the bag, and these were found in it - he said nothing at first, but afterwards said it was a mistake.
Prisoner's Defence My friend was to pay for them, and I said, "Have you paid for the whole?" he said, Yes; and I thought he had.

EDMUND NEWMAN
. They had one pair of soles, and the other man and the prisoner paid for them; they stood side by side, and could hear what was said - I think the prisoner was in liquor.
MR. GIBLETT. I think he was rather in liquor.

GUILTY . -
Confined Three Months .

986.
WILLIAM COLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of February , 15 silver thimbles, value 15s., the goods of
Rowland Hastings
, his master .

ROWLAND HASTINGS
. I am a silver thimble-maker , and live in Great Sutton-street
; the prisoner was in my employ for thirteen years. On the 26th of February we watched the prisoner, and he was seen to take these thimbles - we had missed some the day before.

CHARLES CAMERON
. I am an officer. I was sent for on the 26th of February; I took the prisoner, and found in his fob pocket eleven thimbles, and a duplicate relating to four others - the prisoner said he meant to take them back again.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in these thimbles on the 26th of February, of a person I cannot swear to, but I believe it was the prisoner.

JOSEPH AUBERRY
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. I saw the prisoner take the thimbles out of the bowls, and put them into his right hand pocket.

SAMUEL VESTY
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. We were all ordered into the counting-house to be searched, and these were found on the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I earned 30s. of my master, and he stopped 15s. 6d. out of it - my wife and child were turned out of doors; my child is blind, and is an idiot.

ROWLAND HASTINGS
. I had had the prisoner from a boy- he at first had 5s. a week, and went on till he had 24s. a week; if I had been going out on a Sunday, I should have asked him to come and mind my house; he is an object of great pity.
GUILTY. Aged 29.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury. -
Judgement Respited
.

987.
ISABELLA TODD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 1 watch, value 5l., the goods of
Alexander Naughton
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

988.
MARIA REED
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of March , 4 half-crowns, and 2 shillings, the monies of
Thomas Straker
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

989.
MARY ANN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of March, 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 seal, value 3s.; 2 watch-keys, value 2s.; 1 ring, value 2d., and 1 watch-ribbon, value 1d., the goods of
Thomas Walker
, from his person .

JAMES DITTUM
. I was going to my work at half-past one o'clock in the morning, on the 13th of March, and met the prisoner - the prosecutor was following her, crying Stop thief! and she ran towards me; I went to stop her, she turned back; I ran and took her - she fell down, and threw a watch from her; I held her down till the prosecutor came up, and took her - I saw the constable take up the watch, and I took up the case; the prosecutor charged her with stealing it, in my presence - she said it was not her, it was another girl with her.

WILLIAM EVERETT
. I am an officer. I heard Stop thief! called, but did not see the prisoner taken; on going down Gold's-hill I saw the prosecutor, who said she had got his watch from him; she said she had not taken it, but another girl had - she ran, and was stopped; I asked where the other girl threw the watch - she pointed out the place; I took it up, and the witness took the case - the prosecutor gave his name as Thomas Walker - he is master of a vessel.

Prisoner. Q. Did I not say I was not the person? A. Yes; I saw the prosecutor and her stand at the end of Gold's-hill. as I was going on my beat, five minutes before the alarm; there was another girl at the other corner - the prosecutor said it was his watch; he is gone to sea.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the man, who asked me to go home with him; I said I would not - I saw him talking to another woman; I went down Three Cups-alley - he came and took hold of me, and I said, "Let me go - I will walk with you;" we went on to Gold's-hill, and this witness came, and took me.
GUILTY (of stealing, but not from the person. ) Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

990.
JOHN MASON
was
indicted for embezzlement .

THOMAS EVANS
. I am a milkman . The prisoner was in my employ, and was to receive money, which he was to pay as soon as he came home.

FRANCIS DAVISON
. I paid the prisoner 11d. on the 14th of March, about eight o'clock in the morning, for his master.

ELIZABETH FOSTER
. I am in Evans' employ. I never received the 11d. - he says he put it on the table; my master was very sleepy, and we think he took it up.

ELIZABETH DAVIS
. I was in the prosecutor's employ. The prisoner never brought his account right; he never paid me the 11d.

JOHN EDDS
. I met the prisoner on the 16th; I took him up for a waistcoat which he had on; the prosecutor swore to that at first, but denied it afterwards.
NOT GUILTY .

991.
GEORGE HOWSE
was
indicted for embezzlement .

JOHN MARRIOTT
. I am a carman . The prisoner was in my employ on the 25th of February; he sometimes received money for me, and was to bring it me on that day - he received 5s. from Mr. Gray, which he never paid me; he did not return.

GEORGE GRAY
. I paid the prisoner 5s. on the 25th of February, to take to Mr. Marriott, for him to buy a sack of potatoes.
Prisoner. He said I was to bring them - he did not say I was to give it to Mr. Marriott. Witness. I meant it for Mr. Marriott; he had his horse and cart with him.

THOMAS FARRANT
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the 26th of February; I charged him with stealing this - he said he was very sorry, but he had the misfortune to lose it.

GUILTY . Aged 25. -
Confined Three Months .

992.
THOMAS HAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of April , 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 watch chain, value 3s., and 2 seals, value 3s., the goods of
James Dingwell
, from his person .

JAMES DINGWELL. I am a carpenter , and live in Edward-street, Battle-bridge. On the 13th of April I was drinking at the Maidenhead public-house - I came out for a short time, and was sick; I sat down, and saw the prisoner there - he offered me help, and advised me to give him my watch to take into the bar, or perhaps I should be robbed of it; I did not give it him - he unbuttoned my waistcoat, and said by getting the air I should be relieved: he then unbuttoned the band of my trousers: I looked down, and saw my watch hanging, (I believe.) by a button; I grasped at it, but he was too active - he got it, and handed it to another person, who got off; I seized the prisoner, took him into the house, and charged him with stealing it - he opened his waistcoat, and pleaded innocence; he said he was not the man - he then attempted to run away, but he did not escape my notice; I saw an officer, and gave him in charge.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. When was this? A. On Tuesday afternoon - I am sure it was not Monday; I believe I had drank a small glass of gin at another public-house in the morning - I might have some porter at eleven o'clock; we had some ale at the Maidenhead - this happened between four and five o'clock; the ale had not impaired my intellects - I went into a corner which was parted off; I did not sit down in the fifth, there is a stone on which I sat - I was almost asleep when he aroused me; I looked at my watch after he came up - I was not in such a state that I did not know whether I had my watch; he came to me two or three times - I was not asleep, I was heavy.

WILLIAM FOSTER
. I saw the prosecutor on the 13th of April, against the Maidenhead - I saw the prisoner take something out of his pocket and give it to another, but what I cannot say; the other ran away - the prosecutor seized the prisoner, and gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. What did you do? A. Nothing -I did not go after the young man who ran off; he turned too quick for me - I did not see the prisoner put his hand into the prosecutor's pocket, but I saw it against the band of his breeches; I think he was unbuttoning it.

SAMUEL PRIME
. I know the prosecutor - he lodged with me; I saw his watch about two o'clock that afternoon.

THOMAS WOFFINDEN
. I am a Police-officer. I was going round Battle-bridge - the prosecutor had the prisoner by the collar, and charged him with taking his watch; he said he did not take it.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not the prosecutor beastlydrunk? A. No, sir; I believe he was capable of knowing what he was about - he appeared to me to be sensible.
Prisoner's Defence. I am innocent.

JAMES PARKER
. On the 13th of April I was at this public-house - I went for a pot of porter about four o'clock in the afternoon; I saw the prosecutor there very drunk, and several persons were round him - I saw him staggering and stupified; I looked stedfastly at him and did not see any watch in his possession; I think I should have seen it if he had one.

HENRY DAVIES
. On Easter Tuesday I was playing with the prisoner about four o'clock - the prosecutor was outside the door of the Maidenhead, sitting on the flag stone, in the fifth, very drunk indeed; there was no other boy with us - the prosecutor caught hold of him, when we were about half a dozen yards from him.
COURT. Q. What did he say? A. He said, "You have got my watch;" he said, "I have not, I have not seen it;" I had not seen any one with the prisoner.

ELIZA HAY
. I am the prisoner's sister, and am going on for thirteen years of age - I was going to my mother when this gentleman caught hold of my brother, and said, "You have got my watch;" my brother said, "I have not, nor have I seen it;" I had seen my brother before he caught hold of him - he was standing by himself, with his hands in his pockets, and when the prosecutor was going along the boys hooted him, he was so very tipsy.
COURT. Q. Where did the gentleman come from? A. Out of the house, and seized my brother.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .
Second Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

993.
EDWARD HORNSBY
was indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Robert Innocent
, on the night of the 11th of April , with intent to steal .
The prisoner was detected by the Police in the act of breaking through the wall of the prosecutor's house, but the offence had not been completed,
NOT GUILTY .

994.
JOSEPH WREN
was indicted for that
he, on the 17th of March , a certain building within the curtilege of the dwelling-house of
George Tickner
, feloniously did break and enter, and steal therein, 1 live tame goose, price 7s.; 1 live tame gander, price 7s.; 1 live tame duck, price 3s.; 11 live tame fowls, price 30s., and 20 eggs, value 1s., his property .

GEORGE TICKNER. My dwelling-house is the Custom-house at the West India-docks
. I keep poultry in a large out-house, which is enclosed with my garden and dwelling-house, by a wall seven or eight feet high. On Tuesday evening, the 16th of March, about eight o'clock, the fowls were all locked up safe: I went to feed them next morning, and found the tiles taken off, and part of the grape-vine which goes over it down the windowframes were broken, and on the wall were marks of the prisoner's toes having scraped down; they had got in by breaking the window-frames out - I missed all my fowls, two geese, one duck, and twenty-four eggs, which I had marked with a cross in ink on each side.

JAMES LEE
. I am an officer. On Wednesday, the 17th of March, the prosecutor informed me of this robbery, and about four o'clock that afternoon I was going to a house on Bow-common, and met the prisoner with two men named Wilson and McEwen on the side of the Regent's-canal, about half a mile from the prosecutor's; one of the men, not in custody, was carrying a bag across his shoulder: I stopped him, and asked him what he had got - he said he did not know; at that time the prisoner and Wilson walked on - I asked the man how he got it: he said he was employed by one of those men who had walked on; I told Mr. Prendergast to go after them - he went, and hearing somebody behind, they immediately took to their heels and ran - I caught hold of the man who had the bag; we struggled; he knocked me down and got away - I took the bag, opened it, and in it were seven hens, a cock just killed (it was quite warm), a duck, and two live geese: I proceeded on to the house on Bowcommon, having been informed that Wilson lived there - I found a great quantity of property there; I had been there about fifteen minutes, and while I was in the kitchen the prisoner and Wilson came in, and opened the door; seeing me in the kitchen, they immediately ran out of the house - I pursued them over a bridge, and they got away; in the house I found two of the prosecutor's hens, sitting on twenty-four eggs, which he identified - they were marked with a cross; next morning about six o'clock I apprehended the prisoner in bed, at a lodging-house at Stratford, and asked how he came to run away with Wilson the day before - he denied it, and said he had not seen Wilson for a month; he was taken to the office, and stated to the Magistrate that he had seen Wilson.

GRIFFIN. I work at the East India-dock warehouse, and live next door to the prosecutor. About two o'clock in the morning I heard a noise like fowls and geese going in; I had heard some persons go out, but could not see them - I heard a noise two nights.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. When I found what they had in the bag I came away.

GUILTY . -
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Justice Park.

995.
THOMAS GAMBLE
was indicted for
attempting to administer and causing to be taken by
John Thompson
, a certain poison, (i.e.) oil of vitrol, with intent of his malice aforethought to kill and murder him .
SECOND COUNT, calling it a certain destructive thing instead of poison.

JOHN MAXSEY
. I am thirteen years old. I was at the factory where the prisoner worked with Thompson on the 15th of February ; I gave this stuff to Thompson - I do not know what it was; it was a powder - the prisoner sent me to the doctor's for it, and told me to ask for jalap; I paid 1d. for it - it was jalap.
The prosecutor was dumb; his mother undertook to communicate with him by signs, but after the above evidence it was unnecessary.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Gaselee.

996.
JAMES WILLIAM POYNTZ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February, 1 gelding, price 50l. , the property of
George Thorn
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Park.

997.
MARIA WILLIAMS
was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of March , 1 hat, value 30s.; 1 coat, value 4l.; 1 waistcoat, value 15s.; 1 knife, value 2s., and 11 shillings, the property of
Richard Thomas
, in the dwelling-house of Sir
Henry Harding
.

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Park.

998.
SHADRACH MITCHELL
and
JOSEPH WILLIAMS
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William Stevens
, on the King's highway, on the 29th of March , putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 handkerchief, value 9d., and 7 shillings, his property .

WILLIAM STEVENS
. I am a farmer's man , and live at Long-ford. On the 29th of March I came to Hounslow
, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, with a friend; we went to the White Bear, and had three pints of beer between us and another man, who lived in the yard - we then went to the Prince Regent, staid there about half an hour, and two of us drank three pints of beer - I walked about the town, and then went to the Cricketers, on the heath, alone, and had a pint of ale; I got there about halfpast six o'clock, and staid about an hour - the prisoners came in while I was there; I knew them before, and we had a pot of beer together - I got up to come home; they followed me out - Williams caught hold of my arm, and said, "Let us go up to the George the Fourth, and have a pot;" I refused - Mitchell caught hold of my arm, and told me to come along; I refused - they pulled me about one hundred yards: Mitchell then threw me down, and held me, and then they took my handkerchief off my neck - they took nothing else; they ran away, and I after them- I met Dinam, and went with him for Bennett, an officer, who took them in the town, and my handkerchief was found in Williams' pocket - I cannot say which of them took it; I felt Williams take 7s. out of my left-hand pocket - that was not found; I had no purse - I had taken all my money out at the Cricketers, to pay for the beer; they sat at the same table, and could see it - I was not at all intoxicated.
Prisoner Williams. Q. When I came in did you not challenge me to toss for a pot? A. Yes, and I did; I said I had only a few halfpence in my pocket - I did that for a joke.

CHARLES BENNETT
. I am a constable. Stevens came to my house soon after eight o'clock, and complained of having been robbed of 7s. and his handkerchief; I went in search of the prisoners - he told me who they were, but did not go with me; I found Williams against the cage, and apprehended him - I found this handkerchief in his breast pocket, under his smock-frock; he told me Mitchell was one that was with him - I went in search of him; a boy came and told me he was talking to Williams in the cage - I went and found him there, but found nothing on him; Mitchell said the handkerchief was his own - I never heard the prosecutor say it was not his; he was a little elevated, but not drunk.
Prisoner Mitchell. Q. When I was taken, did he not say he could not swear to me? A. I do not recollect it - he described your dress, and said he could swear to your dress.

WILLIAM STEVENS
. This is the handkerchief I had round my neck; I know it by these holes in the middle -I have had it half a year.
JURY. Q. How came you to describe them by their dress? A. I said I could not swear to their names, but their dress; I have known them both nine or ten years, but had not seen them lately.
Mitchell's Defence. I did not lay him down, or take the handkerchief; I followed Williams and him out of the Cricketers, and saw them all going towards the Wellington.
Williams' Defence. I did not lay him down, nor put my hand into his pocket.
NOT GUILTY .
Before Mr. Justice Pask.

999.
JOHN LASHAM
,
THOMAS MORGAN
and
WILLIAM SAGE
were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Gould
, on the 13th of April
, and stealing 50 pairs of shoes, value 10l., his property : and
WILLIAM LASHAM
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen .

JOHN GOULD. I live in Leader-street, Chelsea
, and deal in slops . On the 11th of April I went to bed about eleven o'clock - I was the last person up, and fastened the doors and windows; I have three outside doors - on Monday morning, a few minutes before five o'clock, the milkman called me; I found my shop shutter cut open, and the glass broken - the shutter appeared to have been cut with a knife or saw: there was a hole about eight inches square - here is the piece that was cut out; a place had been chalked underneath - I missed between forty and fifty pairs of men's new shoes, which exceed 10l. in value.

STEPHEN BROWN
. I am a watchman - my beat is at the top of Keppel-street, about twenty yards from the prosecutor's house. On Sunday night, the 11th of April, just as I had called twelve o'clock, I saw John Lasham, Morgan, Sage, and another not in custody, altogether, having some coffee at the stall in the road, where my wife sells coffee to carters, or any body - I knew the prisoners before.

CHARLES HAYWARD HUGHES
. I am a constable of Chelsea. On Monday, the 12th of April, I went to William Lasham's house, No. 30, George-street, Chelsea, between seven and eight o'clock in the morning; I did not see him at home - I went again at night, and saw him - I assisted in searching the premises after taking Lasham, and found a fiddle answering the description in an advertisement; I went again in the morning, and in a dark closet under the stairs leading to his room, I found a basket full of men's new shoes - he sleeps in a room at the end of that passage; I had taken him into custody the night before, and on searching him at the watch-house he took something from the lining of his waistcoat, and dropped it behind him; I took it up - it was two duplicates of men's shoes, one pair of which Mr.Gould swears to - before I took him into custody, as I went up stairs I heard him and his wife quarrelling; she said to him, "Did not you sharpen two knives yesterday to cut Mr. Gould's shutter open?" and in the further progress of the quarrel I heard her say, "If you strike me I will call Murder!" then she said, "What business had you to go and get drunk with the money produced by the stealing of Mr. Gould's shoes?" he said, "You d - d old wh - e, you had as much of the money as I had;" she said, "Mr. Hughes and Brown are coming for you, Mr. Lasham - you will be locked up, Mr. Lasham; you will be hung, Mr. Lasham! Mr. Hughes has got the fiddle;" we then went into the room - Lasham was sitting there naked; I said, "Mr. Hughes is come. Mr. Lasham; do you know any thing about the fiddle I got here to-day?" I then asked if he knew any thing about the shoes - he said No; I asked for his clothes, and found 3s. in his pocket, and 2s. 6d. on his wife - I took Morgan, (who was in custody.) to him at the watch-house, and said to him, "I have been told that you said this morning that Morgan brought the shoes to your house" - he said, "Yes, Morgan brought them;" I took young Lasham into custody first - he denied the charge; he said he had been at the coffee-shop at Knightsbridge on Sunday night with Morgan Sage and young Lee; I asked what time they came back - he said about twelve o'clock; that they had some coffee of Brown, the watchman, and afterwards spent the night under a butcher's pent-house till another watchman drove them away - Morgan was brought to me in custody; I said, "Where did you spend your pay last night?" he said he had been to Knightsbridge; I asked who with - he said nobody; that he came back at half-past ten o'clock, and slept on Mr. Leach's stones all night - they are in Manor-street, near old Lasham's house; I said that was a lie, and told him he had been with the others - he denied it; I found Sage at a house of ill-fame, in Westminster, on Friday.

HENRY GARROD
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Bridge-street, Lambeth. I have a pair of shoes pawned by William Lasham for 2s. 6d., in the name of William West. No. 44, New-cut - the duplicate produced is what I gave him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .
Third London Jury. - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1000.
ROBERT WALL
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 21st of February , of a certain evil disposed person, 1 skeleton clock, value 19l.; 5 other clocks, value 53l.; 4 time pieces, value 30l.; 1 barometer, value 25s.; 1 watch, value 30s., and 2 sacks, value 3s., the goods of
Isaac Leplastrier
and another, he well-knowing them to have been stolen .

MR. ISAAC LEPLASTRIER. I am in partner ship with my son; this property was at our shop in Cheapside, at the corner of Old' Change - I and my son left the shop together about nine o'clock on Saturday night the 20th of February, the door was shut immediately - I have a porter constantly living and sleeping in a room adjoining the shop; the property was all safe then - I received a message from the porter between ten and eleven o'clock on Sunday night; I went to the shop and found it broken open, and property amounting to above 100l. taken, consisting of clocks of different descriptions, none of which has been recovered; the shop had been entered by means of a side door in the passage - they had got in at No. 49, Old'Change; picked the look in a passage, and got round into our shop: my shop is No. 11, Cheapside, and No. 49, Old'Change.

ANN PETTERIN FLOCKTON
. On the Sunday in question between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, I saw some men come up Old'Change, arm-in-arm one was dressed in a light drab coat, he was a stiff upright man: the other was dressed in a blue coat - I saw the one in a light drab coat take a key out of his right hand pocket, and saw them open the door of No. 49, Old 'Change; they both walked in together into the house - I was called by the servant at a stationer's shop opposite, and might be there twenty minutes or a quarter of an hour; and when I came out, I saw a backney-coach standing at the door of No. 49, the coach was No. 44; I cannot read, but know figures very well - there were two 4's on the coach, the coachman held the door open; I saw the man in a blue coat that went in come out, and jump into the coach - then the man in the light coat, brought out a large blue bag as full as it could hold, it was more than he could lift; they put it into the coach; the coachman was at the door all the time - the man who brought out the bag locked the door; put the key into the same pocket as he took it out of, and then got into the coach, the coachman shut the door; they came right up Old 'Change, and turned round by St. Paul's; I saw the coachman as plain as possible - and swear positively that the prisoner is that man - he drove towards me, and no other coaches were coming by; the place was quite clear.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What are you? A. A poor woman - I sweep the street; I mentioned this the day after the robbery, and gave the number of the coach; I do not make a practice of looking at the numbers of coaches - it was a wet day; I do not remember the number of any other coach I saw that day - I was standing on the opposite side - the coach came right facing me and turned round; I saw the prisoner holding the coach door - I saw the number when the coach turned round; it did not go very quick till it turned the corner - the middle part of the number shone like glass - it was a coach; (looking at two figures) that was not the number - that is 27; it did not rain very hard - I saw nobody else near the coach.
COURT. Q. There are not many coaches about on Sundays in that part of the town? A. The stand is just by - there is hardly any traffic on Sundays.

ELIZABETH HOSKINGS
. I am a servant. On Sunday, the 21st of February, I lived at No. 48, Old 'Change, and saw a hackney-coach draw up to No. 49, about three o'clock - the prisoner is the coachman ; I am quite certain.
Cross-examined. Q. What coloured coat had he? A. I do not know - his hat was covered with oil skin; I had never seen him before.

FRANCIS MORRIS
. I am the prosecutor's porter, and slept there on Saturday, the 20th of February - I went to master's house on Sunday morning, at ten o'clock; returned about half-past eleven at night, and on enteringthe door in Cheapside by the key, I found a great deal of property taken - I had locked every thing up secure.

JEREMIAH LEACH
. I was horse-keeper to Mr. Welch, a hackney-coach master in Horseferry-road - he has seven pairs of plates; No. 44 is one pair. On Sunday, the 21st of February, the prisoner drove No. 44 - I remember his going out about half-past seven o'clock in the morning with the coach, but I cannot say whether he drove it; he took it out, and had driven it for three or four days - he ought to have returned at five o'clock in the morning with the coach, but I cannot say whether he drove it; he took it out, and had driven it for three or four days - he ought to have returned at five o'clock in the evening; I cannot say at what time he came, as I was not in the yard.

Cross-examined. Q. He would come home at all hours - just as his fare required? A. Yes; I have known him five or six months - he is honest as far as I know; he wore a shiney hat - it was not oil skin, but looked like it.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I am an officer. I heard of this robbery on Monday morning, the 22nd of February - I went to Horseferry-road, and finding the prisoner drove No. 44 I went to his house, which is about fifty yards from Walsh's, in Horseferry-road, but did not see him; on Monday, the 1st of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I saw him going into the Mansion-house gate - I had gone frequently to where I was directed, but could not find him.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he not going into the Mansion-house to surrender himself? A. That I cannot answer - he was going in with Herdsfield.

CHARLES HERDSFIELD
. I am an officer. The prisoner wrote a letter to my brother to meet him - I went with my brother, and met him by appointment and took him; he surrendered to us.

Prisoner's Defence. I surrendered - the female witness says she was in the house a quarter of an hour, and was in Cheapside when she saw me drive the coach - I do not recollect having been there at all; I am called on at a non plus, or else I could prove to the best of my knowledge I was in the Waterloo-road, and saw some fruitwomen taken to the watch-house for exposing fruit for sale - here is the hat I wore that day, and I had a boxcoat with six capes.

GUILTY . Aged 40. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

001.
JOHN HAYS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Hugh Leslie
, from his person .

CHARLES HERDSFIELD
. On the 29th of March about one o'clock, I followed the prisoner from the Mansion-house, and saw him put his hand into the pocket of a gentleman who turned into the Bank
; the prosecutor then came by, and he took his handkerchief - an apple-woman called out; he then threw it behind him - I laid hold of him, and called the prosecutor.

HUGH LESLIE
. I was near the Bank; I felt nothing at my pocket - an apple-woman called me; I missed my handkerchief - I found it on the pavement; I gave the prisoner into custody.

Prisoner's Defence. Two boy s were walking behind the gentleman; one of them took the handkerchief and threw it behind - I caught it in my hand, and threw it on the ground; another lad was taken and was in Newgate, his friends have been drinking with the officer till two o'clock in the morning, to make it up.

CHARLES HERDSFIELD
. I saw him take the handkerchief; another boy was taken with him, but the bill was thrown out.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1002.
LEWIS HENRY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of March , 1 gun, value 2l. 15s. , the goods of
Richard Groom
.

RICHARD CHARLES GROOM
. I am the son of
Richard Groom
, a gun-maker , of Lemon-street, Whitechapel
. On the 3rd of March the prisoner came to the shop; my brother went out with him to take this gun.

WILLIAM THOMAS GROOM
. I was in the shop; the prisoner came in, and said he wanted to purchase a gun for a gentleman; my brother looked out two - he said if I would go with him to the gentleman in Drury-lane, he would choose one, and send back the money by me; I went with him, and in Fenchurch-street he said; very likely the gentleman might he at his father's livery stables; he took me to Underwood's stables, in Duke's-place - he took one gun off my shoulder, and went in with it, saying, if the gentlemen liked it he would bring me out the money - I waited ten minutes, and then found he had gone through the stable, and out of another door in Mitre-street.
Prisoner. Q. Was not that gun fairly bought? A. No - he was a stranger to me; he came to the shop alone- he was not trusted with it, but was to bring me back the money or this gun.

JOSEPH SHERWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in the London-road. On the 3rd of March, about eight o'clock in the evening, the prisoner pawned the gun.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I considered it was fairly bought- it was to be paid for by concussion caps; I returned to the gate in ten minutes, and he was gone - I had only been to Mitre-street, where my mother lives; the officer said I should not be prosecuted if I told where the gun was; and the father said he would forego proceedings if I got it back.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1003.
LEWIS HENRY
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of December , 4 pairs of boots, value 3l. 3s.; 2 pairs of shoes, value 14s., and 1 bag, value 1s. , the goods of
Edward Cheaper
.

EDWARD CHEAPER
. I am a boot-maker . On the 24th of December the prisoner, whom I had seen once before, came and selected four pairs of boots, and two pairs of shoes; he directed me to send my lad with him to Langbourn-court, Fenchurch-street - I gave him an invoice of the goods; and gave my lad goods, and a receipt for the money, to deliver to the prisoner - he fully understood it was forready money, and said if I wrote a receipt, there would be a gentleman there who would pay the lad; they went away together - the lad returned with out money or boots - I apprehended the prisoner this day fortnight.

EDWARD GIBBS
. I am the prosecutor's errand-boy. I was to go to Langbourn-court with the prisoner; master gave me a receipt to give the gentleman for the money - the prisoner heard that; I was not to part withthem without the money - the prisoner took me down Jewry-street
, and gave me a shilling to get changed, as he wanted some halfpence, and said he would hold the bag the while; I went into a public-house - they could not give me change, and when I came out the prisoner was gone with the goods.
Prisoner. The prosecutor has known me a long time; I have been frequently at his shop.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years for each offence .

1004.
THOMAS OVERALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of March , 7 3/4 lbs. of hog's lard, value 4s. , the goods of
Mary Lyons
.

MARY LYONS
. I keep a cheesemonger's shop in Winchester-street, London-wall
. On the 3rd of March, between eight and nine o'clock in the morning, I was in the parlour - an officer brought the prisoner in with this bladder of lard, and I missed one from my window.

ABRAHAM HAM
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner walk into the prosecutor's shop and take this lard from the window - he ran across the street, and I secured him with it.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had been ruined by the failure of the Wellingborough Bank. He received a good character.

GUILTY. Aged 42. -
Strongly recommended to mercy .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1005.
EDMUND LAURENCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of March , 1 handkerchief, value 6d., the goods of
William Hall
, from his person .

WILLIAM HALL. On the 20th of March, about half-past nine o'clock in the morning, I was in Cheapside
, and heard the officer call, Stop sir! - I turned round and he was scuffling with the prisoner, who I saw throwing my handkerchief down; I had not felt it taken.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I am an officer. I was in Cheapside, and saw the prisoner in company with another, following close behind a gentleman - I followed him a few yards, then saw him put his left hand into the gentleman's pocket,' take his handkerchief and secrete it under his coat; I collared him, he struggled to get away, and at the same time threw the handkerchief behind him - the other ran off; I called the gentleman, who took the handkerchief up and gave it to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw a person run across the road - I had not gone two steps before this man took me, and he laid down the handkerchief himself.

GUILTY . Aged 16. -
Transported for Life .

1006.
JOHN WILKIE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of April , 1 tin box, value 1d.; 2 sovereigns, and 9s., the property of
James Kalman
, from his person .

JAMES KALMAN. I am a labourer . On the 7th of April, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the day, I was in the street with a tin box in my side-pocket, containing two sovereigns and 9s. - as I crossed the street from a coach, there was a crowd, and before I could get in among the crowd, I felt a hand at my pocket and missed my box; it was picked up with nothing in it but a ticket - I took the prisoner's hand out of my pocket; he ran off - I followed him, and he was taken without getting out of my sight; I did not see him throw the box down.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am an officer. On the 7th of April, I saw the prisoner running very hard and looking very agitated - the prosecutor was behind him calling Stop thief! I said, "What have you lost?" he said a tin box - I called out, Stop him! and a man stopped him: two more ran away down Old Gravel-lane, behind Houndsditch, and the box was found thrown over a yard in that direction.(Box produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. When I was taken I was quite round another street - several people were running.

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Life .

1007.
JOSEPH HARROW
was indicted for
